description:
The food was good. The service was very good. The ambience was the let down as it was very quiet. Think there was only one table and that was on a Wednesday night. I did enjoy the attention from the servers though, since they didn't have other tables to tend to. 
The shared apps were nice- Brussels sprouts were had! The bread was also homemade and a good one to have with the salami plate. 
For main I had the salmon which was good. Also tried all of the desserts as we were a group.
author: Derek M.

description:
Stopped by for a burger and fries lunch special on a weekday. Burger was pretty well made, bun was perfectly toasted, and fries were thin with a good crispiness. 

Its probably 3.5 stars overall for me, but think my concern is that while the place seemed to be on the more posh side, there wasn't anything that amazed me in my experience. Food was also a bit on the pricier side. 

Overall, this place is pretty convenient and great location, service is solid, food is on the more side. Would recommend it if you are in the area and think the menu looks good.
author: James S.

description:
Go to lunch spot with my colleagues when the company is buying! Unfortunately, the menu is pretty limited.

Although we typically go for the Shanghai noodles (which are absolutely delicious), today I opted for a burger (specified bunless by me) and fries.

Burger was well cooked and they accommodated my request. However, I ordered a blueberry iced tea that look & tasted like pink lemonade even though our server insisted that it wasn't. My coworker tried a sip and had to agree. It was so sickenly sweet I had to send it back and get a plain ice tea instead.

I would recommend for a quick bite, but don't expect a large selection. Also, note that they don't honor their check-in deal for lunch, disappointing.
author: My N.

description:
Not happy with this place.  We had a party of 14 on Mother's Day and as expected, Trace is not busy.  We KNEW that this place would be overpriced, BUT, we came for the nice decor and relaxing environment and just wanted to get away from the usual Mother's Day crowd... what we didn't expect is the POOR and INATTENTIVE SERVICE.

From the moment my party was seated, we were pretty much ignored the entire time while other tables were being served and greeted.  Our server was nowhere to be found.

What seemed like a long time (I'm sure it's like 5-10 mins) someone finally brought the table water.  We waited some more...  Still, no menu, no waiter, no greeter.  My sister finally walked to the Maitre 'd to complain about this.  Then long behold, the waiter FINALLY arrived.  By this time, we're 25 mins in after being seated.  Well, he simply passed some menus around and then left... again..  and again, no where to be found.  By the way, he was also short 3 menus... ok, no big deal I guess; we can share.  But this just speaks to the level of inattentiveness.

Then, after reviewing the menu for another 10'mins, we need to FIND OUR WAITER so that we can order our food.  My sis has to go to the Maitre'd to ask for someone to help us, AGAIN.  This time, we're told that there are actually 2 servers who back each other up and apparently, our primary server is pretty awful and the other waiter was supposed to pick up the slack...  well, sorry, I don't really care!  Can we just get some help here, and mind you, we're paying $20 for a bagel here so I do expect some service!! 

Well, throughout our brunch, my sis pretty much had to coach the waiters every step of the way...  take away the empty coffee cups, more half and half for coffee please, more sugar, more coffee, more water, take away the empty plates...  what the heck! 

For our party of 14, we pretty much ordered everything on their limited menu.  All items tasted decent to pretty good, but everything is twice the price than what one might expect to pay :

$16 pancakes -- very good, 3 very fluffy pancakes
$23 smoked salmon bagel -- good but a similar bagel at New York Bagel would be $7
$28 Crab benedict -  pretty good
$19 Chicken Club sandwich -- ok, but awful chips 
$16 -- Steel cut oatmeal.  Well, it's oatmeal 

When servers brought out the plates, they were very confused and did not have a clue which plate goes where and simply yelled out the name of the dish, waiting for us to raise our hand to claim the entree.

AWFUL SERVICE.  Again, we KNEW we'd be paying for mediocre food but we came for the nice ambience and to avoid the crowd.  What we didn't come for is a 18% mandatory gratuity and awful service.  

Yep, there is a reason why this place is never busy.
author: Winnie W.

description: Burger is good, although the place seems to be not that busy / popular as it should. Close to SFMOMA so could be a place to eat before visiting the museum
author: Jing H.

description:
Really a 3.5, but there are a number of reasons I'm deciding to round down.

First, I'd stopped in here for apps and drinks with friends before and already had the impression that the food was good but overpriced.  I finally planned to come here for dinner after purchasing a TravelZoo deal $69 dinner for two that included one Share dish, two "Taste" dishes, and two Mains, plus 20% off bottles of wine.  Without this deal, I feel that the individual dishes at regular menu prices are delicious but just not amazing enough to warrant the cost.

We selected the charcuterie board for our Share dish. It included paper-thin Italian cold cuts, pan-fried crostini, tomato jam, stone ground mustard and a sharp, cheddar-like cheese.  I love charcuterie and think this stood out as one of the best parts of the meal. 

We were also super happy with our "Taste" plates. I chose Creamy Tomato Soup with Grilled Cheese Toast, and the BF chose Roasted Scallops.  Both of these dishes were flawlessly executed, but here is where things started to go wrong with the service.  No sooner had the Taste dishes arrived then the Mains arrived as well.  Now we also had plates of Flat Iron Steak and Sauteed Branzino on the table that were about to get cold while we finished the hot soup and scallops.  The waiter basically apologized as he was setting the Mains on the table and started the delivery by saying he could return them to be heated.  But, we really didn't want fish and steak to be heated up!

Portions for the Mains were small, while portions for the other two courses were average.  My BF's flat iron steak turned out to be a few slices.  It was properly cooked medium rare, but seemed under-seasoned. It really didn't have very much flavor. 

I was happier with my Branzino.  It was simply but perfectly prepared with a crispy skin, but I definitely wished for a bigger portion. It seemed like barely 3 ounces of fish, and maybe 1 or 2 sliced fingering potatoes with a bit of leeks.  I have to wonder if the portion sizes for the mains weren't down-graded due to our TravelZoo coupon.

Overall, I'm neutral about TRACE as a culinary experience, but it's a beautiful space and I feel overall that it's a good dining experience if you want a relaxed and generally good meal in downtown SF.  Just purchase a deal for value.
author: Sheri W.

description:
Came here for the 2018 Restaurant Week Menu. Made a reservations for 6pm on a Saturday night and there was plenty of seating. It didn't end up being too busy till around 7pm.

Our server was Roger and he was amazing! Really attentive and checked up on our table throughout the night.

My friend and I both opted into their $40 restaurant week deal and wine pairings for an additional $15. The wine pairing consist of 2 wine, a white and red (but you can request something else if you have a preference). For my meal, I ordered the roasted brussel sprouts, Duck confit, and Vanilla bread pudding. My friend got the Pork belly, duck confit, and chocolate ganache.  We also shared an order of their West Coast Oysters.

For the starters, the brussel sprouts had a pleasant crispness to it and the seasoning was good. It seemed more like a dish to be shared than to be consumed by one individual. I tried the pork belly and it had a nice balance of fat to meat. It also had a side of julliened green apples which I didn't really fit with the dish, but I assumed acted as a palate cleanser between bites of the pork.  The highlight of the entire meal definitely had to be the Oysters!  Our server said they were shigoku oysters from Washington and it was served with a mignonette, shallots, and garnished with a piece of small cilantro. Definitely try these if you are a fan of oysters, they were delicious!

For the entree, the duck confit was sadly lackluster. The duck was cooked perfectly fine, but I felt like it was a bit underseasoned. It came with three fried duck croquettes, farro, and some type of greens. It just wasn't that impressive after having a positive experience with the appetizers.

For the dessert, the bread pudding is typical of what you expect. It wasn't too heavy which was nice.  The chocolate ganache was definitely a better dessert. They give you a decent size of ganache. It would have been too rich by itself, but when served with the cookie butter ice cream and marshmallow, it becomes quite the treat. If you are a fan of chocolate, that definitely is the way to go. They also had a kaffir lime Panna Cotta, which I should have tried instead, but alas.

Overall the experience was great. The setting was fancy and intimate, our server Roger was great, and food for the most part was pleasant.
author: Jacky C.

description:
4.5 Stars if that could be a choice!!! 

Came here for restaurant week and had a really enjoyable experience. The restaurant is right next to the MOMA in the middle of SOMA so you'll probably want to Bart out here instead of driving. 

Service was spectacular. Our waiter was very pleasing and you could tell he really likes to work here and he really likes food. Very good with recommendations and explaining how the flavors work together. Also checked up on us after every dish to see if we liked it and talked to us about why we liked it which i appreciate. 

In addition to the set menu we decided to get the wine pairing for $15 and also oysters for $15. ALL SO WORTH IT. 

My first course was the pork belly with a butternut squash puree and finely sliced pears. The heaviness of the pork belly was very well balanced by the squash and pears. But the most amazing part was it's pairing with a glass Riesling. The cold sweet crisp taste of the wine after taking a bite of the pork was remarkable! 

We then had the oysters, which is must say were one of the best oysters I've ever had and would definitely come back and get more. They're fresh oysters from Washington with some champagne vinaigrette, shallots, and cilantro. The shallots and cilantro added a very nice texture that went along with the vinaigrette that enhanced the taste of the oyster. I'm so glad this is on their regular menu.

Main course was the duck confit. The duck was duck. It was tender however I felt it was lacking a little pick of flavor. It did go well with the oats and almond farro but I think I was looking for something a little more. I was impressed with the duck croquette though. Maybe since this isn't on their regular menu that it wasn't as good. 

Lastly, dessert. Chocolate ganache will always have my heart. They gave us a quite a fair share of ganache. I was a bit worried it would be too heavy and I wouldn't be able to finish it, however it came with a small scoop of cookie butter ice cream, a toasted marshmellow, and some graham cracker crumbs that balanced out the ganache quite well. I finished the whole thing. Could've had another plate if I wanted to. 

We had a wonderful time.
author: Tatiana T.

description:
My salmon was fantastic.  Juicy and tasty. I had their famous lemon drops martini.  It was delicious, surprisingly as I'm a whiskey guy. 

Our team were here for an evening of get together.  Good place for large groups.  We received their royal group treatment that came with sparkling mineral water. Best on their menu,  grilled Brussels sprouts. Nom nom. 

Ambience was great and service was fantastic!

Cheers!
author: Edwin R.

description:
Went for lunch, very crowded but the staff was awesome and kept on their game. Very happy about that. I tried out the lamb pastrami and have to say it was incredibly good. Very impressed with the flavor of the dish and liked everything about it. 

Wish there was more of a side option to it, but overall very happy.
author: Ben S.

description:
Went here for the SF restaurant week's dinner option. 

Starters -
     Ahi Tuna Tataki: The tuna was paired with a black olive vinaigrette, which brought out the sweetness of the seared tuna. The creaminess of the avocado really made the dish blend well with all the ingredients. Also, the portion was very generous. :)
     Roasted Pork belly: The pork belly was accompanied by a squash puree.  The pork belly was cooked so that the fatty bits were filled with pork-olicious fat and juiciness. YUM!

Entree - 
     Liberty Farms Duck Breast: the menu listed duck confit croquettes, but croquettes were no where to be found. :( The duck was nicely cooked but we both thought the saltiness of the entire dish made it hard to finish.  Would not order this again without asking for more bread. ;)

Dessert -
     Chocolate ganache bar with cookie butter ice cream: beautifully plated but in terms of taste, it was not very creamy and had more of a cake texture.
     Vanilla bread pudding: Drenched with a butterscotch caramel sauce which made it ultra sweet and the perfect way to finish off the meal.  

Without a doubt, we both thought that the first course was the best dish that suited and satisfied our taste buds.  The decor and environment is great for lunch meetings or client meetings.  It is also located inside the W hotel and just a few blocks away from the conventions center.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I had a really nice lunch during restaurant week.  The restaurant is really modern and sexy in appearance.  Service was good.  The food was good.  I had a kale salad with what I assume were baby kale leaves.  There were two large chunks of bacon in the salad that were reedonkulous!  Wow, they may have been the highlight of the meal.  Its hard to describe what was actually going on there, but it was no ordinary bacon and they were not prepared in an type of ordinary fashion.  Peter L. joined me for lunch and he has the tomato soup and said it was good as well.

The Fish sandwich was large and everything worked well together.  The fish was a good portion and the roll was soft and delicious.

The dessert consisted of an ice cream sandwich.  I'm not going to lie, I was expecting something the size of an It's It, but in actuality, it was the size of a silver dollar.  The chocolate cookies were really good and had some salt crystals that really made the sandwich pop.  The ice cream was nothing special, but it was a nice little treat after the meal.

The lunch is $15 and it misprinted on the restaurant week list which has it listed as $25 in the index.
author: Ty C.

description: Earlier after sfmoma, we decided to come here to have a little brunch. I had their grapefruit and avocado toast with a glass of OJ, which was perfect for a hot day out. Grace ordered their French toast which was really yummy too! It was a bit pricy but we knew it would be the moment we walked into the W.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I came here for a business lunch and had a great experience. It wasn't overly crowded and our server was amazing. We checked in and got the free share plate but since we had a bigger party he gave us 2 servings instead. 

We had the Brussels sprouts and it was really good. I ordered the shanghai noodles and loved it. There was a ton of mushrooms in it. My coworkers ordered their burger and said it was perfectly cooked. 

Their passion fruit lemonade was also really really good. My coworker ordered the blue berry ice tea and said it was mediocre. 

Definitely thumbs up!
author: Mai W.

description: Brunch only. Really good Croque Madame - outstanding flavor and freshness. Due to the ho hum reviews on Yelp I did not have high expectations, but as I was staying in the W and about to move on to a different part of the city I thought I would stay close for Sunday brunch. Again, everything was incredibly flavorful. The sandwich was served with a nice side salad of arugula radish and some greens, and it provided a bright compliment to the sandwich. Service was fast and attentive - very positive. A one star deduction for not-so-hot coffee (I can't stand coffee that's not piping hot), as well as a pretty limited menu. I understand not wanting to do too much, but I think people have a certain expectation for brunch, and honestly it would not be difficult to put some more mainstays on the menu. Very good meal.
author: Brian W.

description:
Service: decent. Server was the only for the entire restaurant with some help from the bar staff, which didn't blow our socks off. but the help from other staff made it a bit better.

Food: [Appetizers] We ordered (2) of the Brussel Sprouts, they were so delicious! Perfect amount of carmelized sweetness with a little savory from the mustard seed and fried to perfection.  The chicken liver mousse was predictable and had to ask for more crostinis to go with it (isn't that always the case?

[Entrees] Two orders of the burger with fries and two orders of the steak. Burgers were really yummy and better than I thought for hotel food. My steak was supposed to be medium rare, but came out more medium than rare. Bummer. It came on a splattering of basic polenta and a few sauteed mushrooms. The steak not being cooked to my liking was one thing, but chewy and bland from the mushroom sauce. The polenta was a bit too "watery" for what i'm used to and lacked salt/flavor. 

Many other restaurants in the City to dine at, but this is decent if you're a traveler. The pricing is a bit high for the quality of the food, so I'll be taking my money elsewhere.
author: Heather C.

description:
I wanted to find a restaurant to meet a friend after visiting the SF MoMA and this popped up right next door, so I figured why not. When I got there, the maitre d informed me that if we wanted to wait they might possibly have a booth ready for us. 

The restaurant was empty, save for 2 other diners. This was the strangest thing ever. Throughout our lunch service, only two more people showed up. Not sure who he was trying to squeeze into those booths because they must have been invisible.

Anyway, aside from that very strange encounter, I had a pleasant time here. Very modern and chic, so just the place to go for a trendy lunch/brunch. Prices were very reasonable. I ordered the chilaquiles, which was quite tasty. I should have asked for less tortilla chips, but it was a decent portion and the food came out very quickly. The iced coffee was water tbh (very weak). I literally did not taste coffee. 


Overall had a nice experience with quick service (considering we were two of the only people in the restaurant this makes sense).
author: Jin C.

description:
I've come here a few times for dinner and lunch, and it's time for an overdue review. What can I say, I'm a fan of their food, and a huge fan of their ambiance. Modern, clean, and with a (slightly bougie) Vegas nightclub feel, Trace is a trendy place to take a date. 

I decided to come here for lunch yesterday and ordered the Veggie sandwich. I sometimes find it hard to find a tasty veggie sandwich or burger done right, but this place pulled it off. The patty was cooked just right - nice, savory and NOT DRY (huge plus). And they stuffed the crap out of it with avocado (another huge plus). I came in exceptionally hungry, and left exceptionally full. 

Service was on point, staff was attentive (and even had a few jokes to spare), and I even noticed a few people coming here to work (holla, that might be me next time). Overall, Trace has never disappointed me, and I don't anticipate them to when I dine and chill here.
author: Rebecca L.

description: Breakfast was amazing! Really glad we decided to come in before checking out of our room
author: Brittany N.

description:
The best W restuarant decor that I've seen, it reminds me of the Swarovski curtains at the Cosmo in Vegas. 

The food was great. Although a bit overpriced for the quality, but great. I would recommend coming here for drinks after dinner, and just skip the meal here. It's hard to get a booth, so try to make reservations in advance. Such a nice and great place for a girl's night out. 

The service was OK, not that memorable or went out of their way in any way.
author: M T.

description:
Stunning and spacious venue with fringe decor. Definitely a great place to have a business lunch or a nice evening meal. Acoustics are great so even during the busiest time of day, you can still have a great conversation without feeling to overrun. 

Service is attentive, friendly, and staff are willing to thoroughly go through the menu. They check in frequently without seeming too swoopy. 

Food is amazing, and presentation of main dishes are top notch. If you do go, definitely get a side of bread. Thick crust with olives baked in definitely kicks off your meal well. The salmon seasoning is unparalleled, particularly the parsnip puree mixed in with the oriental glaze. 

Because it's a hotel restaurant, particularly the W Hotel, it's on the pricier side, (example, a flatbread appetizer will run you about $17, and a bowl of brussels sprouts will be about $11, salmon with light sides of edamame for lunch will run about $28). It's more than worth it to hit up this place during restaurant week as you can get a multi-course meal plus kick it off with their fresh juices for $25. Portions aren't reduced either, so you're really in for a treat.
author: Alison A.

description:
Great spot for travelers or an after work crowd. Not cheap but high quality food and drink. Friendly wait staff. Comfortable atmosphere that's easy to get comfortable in. Wonderful lighting and upbeat music that wasn't too loud

Well stocked bar and a wide range of custom cocktails. Not cheap but fit the neighborhood and atmosphere

Easy access and great location. Great spot to get some friends together with lots of places to go before or after

Gender neutral bathrooms
author: Cole E.

description: Very modern decor. The brunch menu is completely - and I repeat, COMPLETELY - overpriced. However, the waitstaff was extra attentive, and everything was delicious. We ordered the Trace breakfast and steak and eggs. Two thumbs up.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This place is inside the W hotel. My friends and I came here last night for Restaurant Week. Their menu had a good selection of foods. I tried the shigoku oysters, the Trace burger, and the kalamansi meringue tart for my 3 courses. They also pair your order with either a red or white wine. 

I think the appetizers were the best part. Everything was delicious! The oysters were delicious. But if you're not into seafood, I'd highly recommend their fried Brussels sprouts. They were made well and had great flavor. The Shanghai noodles were amazing too. 

The burger was more so your typical burger, but with a slight twist with the dill aioli. That added a good flavor to the burger.

The tart was tart, but not too tart, which was great. It paired well with the meringue on top. 

Overall, I would definitely come again. The wait staff was friendly and the atmosphere was great.
author: Karen Y.

description: I don't know what Trace and the W Hotel recently changed (as I dined here a year ago, and that meal was OK)...but my recent Trace dining experience was perfection and rivaled Napa Valley high-end cuisine.  I ordered the tomato soup, endive & pear salad, and broiled king salmon.  Each plate was a "best of" gastronomical experience.  The executive chef and his/her staff should be praised, and diners should go out of their way to experience Trace.  I should also note that the hostess and wait staff were terrific, too.  Roger was knowledgable, attentive, and fast; I appreciated his contributions to this outstanding dining experience!
author: Rick L.

description:
Well, if you've ever wondered what the worst charcuterie in the world tastes like, come here and wonder no more.  Table agrees that this is the saddest/worst charcuterie anyone's had...by far.  Rest of the food wasn't anything memorable. Drinks were delicious hence the second star, however not.2$ sign for sf.  Service was better than decent.  I can't get over how awful the charcuterie was. Scallops were underdone and only 3 small ones for the price.  

Another notable disappointment is that all of the vegetables on each of the plates were more bitter than expected.  Though we all came hungry, no one picked their plates clean.

Overall, disappointed.

My husband wanted to note that the burger didn't have any tomato.   I know that's not a huge deal but just gives and example of disappointing surprises during the meal.
author: Natasha B.

description:
Delicious food, excellent service, nice décor.

It's located near the SFMOMA in the W Hotel so it's in a great location. There was a good selection on the menu and we ordered a variety of appetizers in addition to our entrees and desserts. There were people at only half of the tables so our servers were very attentive, but I think they would have been even if the restaurant was full.

The interior is not dark and fairly quiet--we liked it but we know others like background noise. There are large windows with a nice view of Yerba Buena as well as an interesting view inside of the second floor.

Portions were actually generous compared to other high-end restaurants where we've dined but things are a la carte so be prepared. The bill ended up being several hundred dollars for the two of us. It was a splurge for us, but since it was for a special occasion, we enjoyed the experience.
author: Mj S.

description: We were over charged ($34 for a hamburger), unfortunately we didn't realize it until we got home. We called the restaurant and left messages but no one responded.....
author: Deirdre C.

description:
I tried TRACE for SF Restaurant Week with a friend. I'd previously been here for a Yelp Elite event but wasn't that impressed, but their restaurant week menu definitely pulled me in! For $25, TRACE offered an appetizer and entree, complete with a juice of your choice.

I ordered the fried brussel sprouts, chicken katsu salad, and the kale, spinach, cucumber, apple and ginger juice. I loved the brussel sprouts! They were crispy and slightly sweet, with pecans sprinkled throughout. The chicken katsu salad was definitely not what I expected. It was basically a large chicken katsu cutlet, with a cabbage salad on top of the cutlet (see picture!). It was great though! It was an inventive way to present the dish and it was really photogenic as well. :-) The cutlet was fried well and didn't have too much breading. The juice had good flavor, but I wish it came with ice because it was a little room temp. It tasted like a drink that would give me a nice detox haha! I also tried some of my friend's pork skewers, which were basically meatballs, but they were super yummy! The meatballs had a glaze on them that made them a little crunchy on the outside. I also had a bite of the king salmon and that was delicious as well, with the black bean sauce!

Service was very friendly and the interior was verrry nice! I also saw they have a normal set lunch menu so maybe I will return for that!
author: Tara A.

description: The food was alright, and the staff was nice enough. But what brought us into the restaurant was the Yelp coupon, which they actually didn't honor.
author: Neel S.

description: French Toast was good, not so fancy but soft, just the way I like it. Nothing special with the scramble egg. The Server was friendly and fast.
author: Maria S.

description:
Overall my feeling after leaving was, "meh".  

The actual space and design is on point, but the vibe is off because it feels like a ghost town.  We had dinner on Saturday night, and we were literally one of about 4-5 tables.  Even with the limited number of people, we had incredibly slow service.

There were two stand out items that we had:  the tomato jam (part of the charcuterie appetizer), and the heirloom tomato salad.  Both were actually amazing, but our waiter Roger mentioned that they were both on their way out as tomato season is over.

I think our overall experience would have been much better if the steak was better.  Honestly I could have cooked the steak MUCH better on my George Foreman at home.  It was disappointing to say the least.
author: Chad D.

description:
W is a small hotel and so is the restaurant. The decor is very beautifully done and the restaurant seems to be very slow. 

The food was above average but nothing too exceptional. We still think that LUCE at intercontinental wins over trace. 

Their Brussel sprouts are really nice. If I go back, I'll make sure to order them. 

We also shared the duck which was also delicious, tender and flavorful. 

Their wine list is great too. They have cheaper wines on the menu ranging from $30 per bottle -$90. We ordered a $50 bottle which was also really nice.
author: Ghazal P.

description: Terrible experience. We came here for a birthday dinner. Food was decent, but service was rude. It was part of a deal with Travel Zoo so we had a discounted meal, but waiter Roger treated us as if we were ripping them off. Service charge at 20% ($25!) was automatically added based on the undiscounted value of the meal so it's not clear how he would be losing out. He spoke condescendingly when we wanted clarification on the bill and when we asked for a complimentary birthday cake that was promised to us at the beginning by the maitre d', waiter made it a point to let us know that we already had a great deal and they don't usually give cakes. Pretty ridiculous from a restaurant at a W hotel. Not very classy. A neighboring table was using the same deal and also seemed to be complaining. All customers should be treated the same. Maitre d' was nice. Wont be coming back.
author: Rob H.

description: I went to Trace yesterday for Mother's day dinner with my family. The food was nothing special but there were a few dishes that stood out compared to others. I would go back again but only to order the charcuterie platter and their burger. Everything else we had: the steak, the pork loin, the halibut, and the salmon, were all decent but like I said, nothing special. Not sure if I would go back again. Also, their non-alcoholic drinks, the passion fruit lemonade and strawberry soda were all too sweet and sour. But their decor is really nice!
author: Stephanie Z.

description: Amazing restaurant week menu, duck confit cooked at right level and bread pudding is very smooth
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Located next door to the Museum of Modern Art in a trendily decorated space, this place is both convenient and super tasty! 
We had brunch. The chilaquiles and the croque madame were beautiful. Just an amazing mix of flavors cooked perfectly. But what was out of this world was the nondescript Bloody Mary. Steve Buscemi would not have approved as there was no celery, but I have to say the taste was AMAZING!!! Bloody Mary fans have got to try this one!!! Trust me!
Service, decor, and taste are all two thumbs up. I highly recommend dining here.
author: C C.

description: Came here today for lunch with a party of 12. We walked in and it was mellow, which is not surprising for 12:45pm on a Thursday in the middle of the week. We asked for a table, and they immediately began to join 2 long high-top tables to accommodate our large party. We were seated within a few minutes. The server came around to take our drink orders, and soon after, our food orders. The "On the Fly" lunch special is well worth it for $20. You were given the option of fried Brussels sprouts or the Sweet Potato and Lentil soup as a starter. Then you could choose between the Burger or Shanghai noodles as your entree and each guest was given a small salted chocolate cookie and vanilla ice cream sandwich. The service was quick. My burger was cooked perfectly medium, as stated in the menu. I would love to come back to try dinner!
author: Nicole R.

description:
We recently had the pleasure of staying at W Hotel in San Francisco Jan 13-16. We had breakfast daily at Trace and couldn't be happier with the service and fare! The decor is something amazing and everything was perfect. I only recall a couple of our waiters names, but would love to commend them. Chris and Yeahea (?) Super friendly, attentive and personable fellas! Everything we ordered was outstanding, and the grapefruit juice is even better than I usually have from anywhere else! Big plus: They carry almond milk for my coffee and didn't charge me extra for it ;) 
Highly recommended!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Really awesome service and food! The employees go above and beyond. I have only been here for breakfast but it's spot on, healthy, fast and delicious. Totally check them out if your staying in the hotel or wanting to try something new. Never crowded and the interior is really sweet!
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Disclaimer: 1 star rating due to hidden cost, not food quality or service. 

Received a travelzoo coupon for this restaurant from an employer, and went to check it out tonight. The Maître D' was friendly, but wearing a Penguin Polo and pants, so I thought the feel was pretty relaxed. The Server was super friendly as well, and very helpful in clarifying what our coupon would get: 1 "Share", 2 "Taste", and 2 Entrees. My wife and I shared the fried Brussels Sprouts, kale salad, and Shanghai noodles. I had the salmon entree and she had the steak. Everything was pretty good (portion, flavor, etc). The couple with us also got similar items except they tried the scallops and said they were tasty. 
Other than water, the only drink between the 4 of us: my wife had a glass of Riesling ($12). 
The travelzoo coupons together were $138 worth, and then the wine $12 brought the bill to $150. When the bill came though, there was a $48 "Service Charge", plus tax. I don't begrudge paying the tax outside the coupon, but come on. The service charge is basically a forced 35% tip. So we ended up having to pay $76, which as students, is not ideal. 
My biggest problem is that a tip is supposed to be based on service. And I would have no problem tipping 20% because the service was pretty good. But to force patrons to tip 35% is ballsy. 

To re-iterate: 
Service = 4 stars 
Food = 4 stars 
Cost and hidden fees = 0.5 stars
author: Josh S.

description:
Trace brunch - 2 entrees and mimosa special via TravelZoo.
Las Vegas style in SF. The interior is a hue of white and lavender accented with stainless steel and black. Very chic.
Not busy for a Sunday so being in a quiet setting was a pleasant surprise.
Service staff was friendly and efficient.
We ordered the poached albacore tuna salad and hangar steak and eggs. Food is tasty. Nice presentation. Portion size was reasonable but prices are on the high end.
Good place to visit especially with the discount coupon because in that case, food and price have a good marriage.
author: David H.

description:
Great place for a trendy brunch. The food is always good and consistent (especially the chilaquiles), and the atmosphere is really nice and chill. I'm glad they renovated it from the "server-room" aesthetic they had going previously (it looked like a server room before).

I don't love their coffee, though, but I do love that they give you a whole pot just for your table. And they also have a VIP discount for frequent customers who live in the neighbs.

Oh, and the music is great. :)
author: Bar B.

description:
Treat yourself! 

Although we dinned here on an Travel Zoo voucher the food was absolutely amazing and VERY fresh! They started with a sea food sample, compliments of the chef that was delicious!  
We shared Salmon Rillette which was a generous portion served in a cute little mason jar along with sliced toasted bread. The Shanghai Noddles, was also a hit and again another generous portion!  We also shared the Roasted Scallops, which was my favorite because of the sauce, sweet & spicy with bits of bacon! 

Our main were the Grilled Hanger Steak, just because it was the most expensive item on the menu! We should have stayed with the recommended preparation; medium rare but decided on well done and it was still good, but not like WOW. We did not have room for dessert and left feeling very satiated. 

We will be back!
author: marcus c.

description: Very classy nice restaurant conveniently attached to the W hotel. The staff is very friendly, quick, and gave us our OJ and Coffee on the house. The food is okay breakfast food, the chilaquiles were very good, but a little too soggy. The prices are extremely expensive as well. If you are in a rush and are staying in the W, that is fine, but there is better food in the city,
author: Harry P.

description:
Came here on a Monday evening after a meeting at the Moscone center. We didn't make reservations but surprisingly didn't need any. The restaurant was almost empty, with the exception of a small group that came in after we were seated. That's usually not a good sign, but I have to say, this was an outstanding dinner!
Our waiter/bee keeper Roger was awesome! Super attentive & informative.

Here's what we ordered:

Appetizers:
-Chicken liver mousse
-Shigoku Oysters
-Roasted beet salad

Entrées:
-Broiled King salmon
-Seared Hokkaido scallops 

I'm not a fan of pâté but the chicken-liver was quite tasty. The standout appetizer was definitely the oysters! They came prepared with a red wine mignonette, horseradish crème fraiche...delicious. Anytime I order oysters, I can count on ruining the taste by adding too much horseradish so I loved that they were served with the perfect amount. 
The greens on the salad were very fresh & crisp & the burrata went perfectly with the beets. Roger added the honey to the salad table side.

We shared the entrées. Both were great but the scallops were my favorite. They were served on top of roasted sunchoke, swiss chard & rosemary aigre-doux. Loved the sweet kick! The salmon not only looked good but tasted great. 

Prices were reasonable for the portion size. Unfortunately we had no room for dessert.
I will definitely come back, not only for the good food but also for the excellent service.
author: Adrianna J.

description:
I would give this a 3.5 star rating, but not a 4.
While the menu changes constantly and they rotate things in and out, my favorites over the last few big changes were 
1. whole oat groats served with milk and rosemary.
2. Bone marrow 
3. Shigoku oysters
4. Every now and then the waiter would serve artisan breads (rye with olives baked in them, buttermilk bread, etc) which were so great. 

The price however is a bit over the top.
author: Mima G.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for our anniversary, after finding a coupon on TravelZoo for dinner for two. I was really happy with the service that we received from our waiter, Roger. He was very attentive to our table and made sure to ask what we were there celebrating, even surprising us with a sweet anniversary dessert after. He and the boyfriend got to talking about wines and he even brought us a tasting of his favorite. We thoroughly enjoyed the fig & prosciutto flatbread, heirloom tomato salad & mushroom noodles. I loved my pico de gallo steak and the chicken my man ordered was perfect. I think the W is a cool hotel so it was fun to eat dinner in the hotel there. Thank-you so much for making our anniversary so special. :)
author: M. F.

description: Went here for my 25th birthday lunch with some friends. Food was good, but the portion size was off for the price. Good brews on tap and the roasted bell pepper dip was a good starter. Nice "chill" atmosphere.
author: Virginia C.

description:
We came here during restaurant week and we weren't disappointed. Great space, tall ceilings, plenty of sunlight. The beet salad with burrata, pistachio, and honey was my favorite. Perfect texture for the beet, very creamy burrata with just the right amount of honey. I also really liked the pork should dish. Very tender meat but the best part of the dish is the slightly browned gnocchi. 

If you are trying to decide on a red wine by the glass, get the meritage marsennay from burgundy (2006). I like it better than the Location E from Spain (E is the license plate initial for Spain, quite ingenious marketing for non-appellation specific wine.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Bad experience. 

We made reservation weeks in advance for restaurant week to dine with a group of friends and there was no indication that they do not honor the restaurant week menu during the weekend until a group of us were at the door. Then we were told, they wouldn't honor it, it was a mistake, they should have indicated that they don't serve restaurant week menu on weekends and they will fix it. I mean, if it is a mistake of them, it's not fair for them to expect us to just go with their regular menu. 

I will not return, "great" attempt to advertise for your restaurant!
author: Joyce S.

description:
Since moving to San Francisco 3 months ago, it seems like I've had more visitors here in those 3 months than I had living in Las Vegas for 7 years! LOL, probably not true, however, it seems like every week and weekend, someone new is in town and ready for dinner. Last night was no different. An old colleague of mine came to town on business and wanted to have some dinner. We settled for the W because of the great reputation of the hotel. 

This place is dramatic! Vaulted ceilings and bunched up white lace hung from the ceiling down to the floor. It looked like the Tree of Life on Avatar. I felt like I needed to chant. Lots of white tables and chairs and decor made this place fancy. The service was no different. She was calm, collected and gave a lot of suggestions for drinks and food. Heads up, if you check into Yelp and order two entree plates, you'll receive a coupon for a  share plate for free. Great deal! Here's what I had for dinner:

-My cocktail was the Metropolitan for $15. Michter's Rye Whiskey, muddled raspberries, pink grapefruit, fresh lime, basil and peychaud's bitters. This was a great drink! The whiskey was masked with a refreshing combination of citrus and herbs. I loved it! Highly recommend!

-Our share plate was the Crispy Fried Quail for $16 (free with coupon). 3 pieces of quail on a bed of sour cherry reduction, topped with nicoise olive leaves, shaved celery and hazelnut. The quail was fantastic! Nicely breaded and fried, the cherry sauce wasn't too sour, really complimented the dish  well. Loved the refreshing texture you got from the celery as well. 

-For dinner, our server suggested the Winter Dungeness Crab meal, a new dish to the menu, for $30. Crab meat mixed with root  vegetables matignon, shaved black truffle on top, meyer lemon, parsley over a bed of creamy white polenta. For starters, I didn't taste polenta. There were some here and there, but for the most part it was a soup on the bottom. Not a lot of crab meat. It seemed that way because they shred it all over the plate, however, you got a lot more parsnips, carrots and brussel sprouts. It was just OK. I do like that they incorporated butter into the dish for the sake of the crab. Points for that. 

What a beautiful restaurant. Minus some minor details, I really liked it! I love that they offer just as many seafood dishes as they do meat dishes. I'm definitely coming back on another night. You should check them out!
author: Rockne H.

description:
The food here is OK, hence the two starts. 

What I am really dissapointed was the service. Their cake cutting service was AWFUL. 
I brought a cake for my friend and asked them if they would bring the cake out after we were done eating, it was supposed to be a surprise.  The maître d' informed that their was a cost of $4 per person, so I asked if they would just bring out plates and forks and a butter knife so I could avoid the cost. The maître d' said he would wave the fee. 

The waiter sets out the plates and forks (it was supposed to be a surprise, I dont know why it was set before hand) and he brings out the box with the cake inside and says he pre cut it for us. It was cut all throughout the middle and you couldn't even see the writing! Additionally he says that he only cut a couple pieces for us, but those pieces were all in the middle and we were leftover with two large pieces on the side! Everyone was shocked at how poorly the cake was presented. 

Never again will I be going to TRACE!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
I consistently come in for breakfast if I'm staying at the W but I never considered coming for dinner since I generally avoid hotel restaurants. Luckily I was waited upon by Roger. Part beekeeper, part exceptional server, Roger was excellent. Food was solid. Overall, I was impressed.

It's almost blasphemous to recommend the restaurant at the W in San Francisco, but if you don't have the time or the patience to find the perfect restaurant in SF or wait for a table at one of those restaurants, Trace is decent alternative.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Trendy brunch place. The decor is beautiful. We were here on Sunday with party of 12people. The staff was very attentive and friendly. Food was amazing, I loved the passion fruit lemonade  and smoked salmon.

I will visit again to try there dinner menu. Love this place.
author: Sheetal M.

description:
Who works over two full-time jobs without  pay or a yearly raise?
Mom's that's who.
So, for a belated Mother's Day gift (since I was out of the country), I decided to take my mother here for a nice brunch.

It's conveniently located near the SF MOMA, and within walking distance to the Powell Street Bart station.

My mother ordered their vegetarian omelet while I had their steak and eggs.
I also ordered a chai almond milk and a kale and greens juice.

Mom: "With the price you're spending on this meal, you could have bought me a ticket to the Motown Musical at the Orpheum Theatre."

This is my mother on a good day, in a good mood.

Me: "I thought this would be a nice treat; brunch downtown."

Mom: "That's the problem with you and thinking."

Anyways, back to the food, I was disappointed with the portion of the steak. It looked like one steak kebab, and that was all. And the chai almond milk was a joke. It was 90% ice, and after two sips at $9, I found it to be an incredible waste of money.

Maybe mother was right after all.

The service was slow, since the waitress was taking care of all the tables, and the kale juice thing was awful. It was extremely bitter, and again, this was also filled with ice cubes, so it was like paying another $9 for a cup of ice.

My mother didn't really like her omelet since the house potatoes were semi-raw and not crispy. I tried to give her my crispy potatoes, but by then she was over Trace's food, and just wanted to leave.

Mom: "See smarty pants, paying more for brunch doesn't always mean it's going to be better."

At nearly $80 for two people, mother is right once again.
author: Jack R.

description:
Came here with my in-laws when they were visiting from LA.
They are pretty fancy people and this was a pretty good option. The environment was nice, the food wasn't crazy expensive, and the servers were really attentive. I mean....REALLY attentive like "go-away and stop coming here so much" attentive.
author: Julianna I.

description: The pear salad was great. The King Salomon was excellent. The service was fine. Overall very good food.
author: Gal S.

description:
The review is for the brunch fare on a Saturday when I had to use my Gilt promotion before it would expire.  For $29 I could snag for two persons: mimosas, 1/2 fresh juice and any entree.

The traces of mmm +'s:
+ Mimosa came in requisite flutes and they were easy to imbibe
+ For $9 you can get the full glass of green juice that tastes great after pounds of leafy greens have been pulverized to a decent blend.
+ Steak and eggs ($21) included fingerling potatoes which were awesome! The side salad was lightly dressed and clean. The scrambled eggs were crazy fluffy and amazing!
+ Pancakes ($14) were on the menu and I'll say I was tempted but did not try it. We saw an order go by our table and the stack was huge and airy. Visually it looked divine.
+ Decor is modern and trendy. I dig the white glossy tables and silvery curtains that separated those in the booths and those on the floor. 
+ Excellent service. We were never left unintended.

The traces of errr -'s:
- Coffee is $5.50 with free refills. Err, I think it's a bit much.
- Medium rare steak was cooked to practically medium. Bummed but my fault for not complaining especially since the waitstaff had asked pointedly how was the steak.

Great place to have breakfast but just parking kills. 

TIP: Watch for the service charge that may be included in the bill. For my visit, the service charge was part of the total due.
author: Yiven C.

description:
3.5 stars. An upscale lunch at the stylishly chic and modern W hotel, who wouldn't enjoy that? I really liked the modern simple and clean design of this dining area. The atmosphere gave off a relaxing feel. I really like those white drapes around the table booths, they remind me of those around a princess' bed. 

On to the food - We got the brussel sprouts, chicken liver mousse, mushroom flatbread, and almost the entire table got their hanger steak $22 (medium rare). The food was tasty and the steak was cooked perfectly, but they didn't really blew me away. For the price, I think they have delivered what was expected and the presentation of the food was great! If you plan to get dessert, I would recommend getting their chocolate cake or pumpkin cheesecake. They both looked and tasted good. I wouldn't recommend getting their ice cream sandwich because my friend said it was just like oreo cookie stacked with ice cream in the middle, not very special. The food presentation is great but the taste points can be improved. The service was a bit slow since we waited for our server to get the check, but the service was friendly nonetheless.
author: Hoyan L.

description:
High noon in SoMa is near impossible to find a seat and get a quick lunch before facing up to a Ridiculous Meeting Schedule Day Part 2. 

Trace is just that shelter in the maelstorm. They offer an amazing $20 prix fixe three-course lunch menu in a beautifully lit dining room with soothingly kind wait staff. Lunch here is like a mid-day spa retreat for the mind and body.

The Lunch on the Fly menu offers a rotating selection of two entrees and two salads pairings. I had a beautifully prepared beet salad, chicken thighs on a spiced bed of farro, and the standard dessert, an ice cream sandwich. My dining companion had a lovely peach salad, pork skewers, the ice cream sandwich.

The portions are generous, and I was congratulated several times about having finished my salad and entree. (What the ? Do I look like a frail convalescent?)

I'll be back when the burger is on the On the Fly menu, and to do research on the happy hours offerings!
author: Mutant O.

description:
We HATED this place called Trace. It's a place where the pace of the food delivery and service is so bad that it brought frowns to our face - what a disgrace. Oh what a disgrace! The waiter must have misplaced our order and then did nothing, absolutely nothing about it for over 45 minutes! What a head case!

We arrived at 11:54 am (Google told me that), was promptly seated in a nice booth. We promptly ordered. After about 30+ minutes, we realized that somethings wrong. Called over the waiter. Came back in ten minutes and said we were ticket #3. We said "hey fella, we've watched people come and go ordering the same burger yet here we sit!". The manager checked but did nothing. One would think that they would rush our food through - nope, nada. We left at 1:31 pm after eating a turkey burger and fries. You would have thought this was a multi-course Moroccan place.
author: Matt T.

description: I had breakfast at TRACE with some friends this morning and had a great experience.  The restaurant is beautifully decorated, the service was friendly and super quick and the food was quite tasty too.  I enjoyed some yummy orange juice and the buttermilk pancakes that were so light and fluffy.  Definitely a quiet place to enjoy some breakfast, but beware that it is pretty pricey!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
If you're wondering if you should get the Travelzoo brunch certificate, definitely do it. The brunch here was solid.

* French toast: Very savory (not on the sweet side) - you could have told me it was a quiche and I would have believed it. But it was delicious.

* Eggs chilaquilles: Good. It's a bit on the decadent side (which is hard to discern from reading its description alone) - basically an eggs and nachos dish with hot sauce and guacamole.

* Oysters: A bit on the expensive side (4 for $14) but it was very good! There is some jalapeno that added just enough "bite" to it. 

Service was very good (the restaurant was relatively empty when we came in at 12:30pm)
Protip: The gratuity will already be included in your bill if you're using Travelzoo. So look at the bill when you get it.
author: Sylvia L.

description: Found this nice but pricey (reason for four out of five stars) restaurant at the W hotel. I chose this place because of the menu and alcohol choices. I enjoyed my kale salad with bits of butternut squash. My main dish was the King Salmon and you could tell it was fresh. Cooked perfectly.  My wife enjoyed her scallops but was surprised they gave her a large plate for just the scallops alone. It looked slightly off and probably would have looked better smaller plate or centered. I had a local craft beer and wife had glass of her favorite Riesling wine. Although it was expensive, we enjoyed the decor, the service and the food.
author: Louis A.

description: Went here for lunch after a great show at MOMA, and was totally blown away!  Wonderful waiter, imaginative menu, realistic prices and absolutely wonderful food. I was a bit suspicious when the dining room was only half full at 1pm on a rainy day, and I had been to the previous restaurant in that space (XYZ) and had been very dissapointed, but this time it was different. My three friends all had the OTD Specials (Out The Door, designed for folks on the go) but we were in no hurry, and sat at a table. The OTD Specials were tasty and a good value at $20. I on the other hand was quite hungary and opted for the pork on polenta dish which was TO DIE FOR!  I don't often frequent restaurants in hotels but I will most certainly be back, and soon!
author: Chris P.

description: Here for lunch while on business. Food tasted great and prices are what you'd expect in the downtown of any large city. Had the tomato soup, olive mix, and mortadella sandwich, all of which were excellent. Wait staff was friendly, fast, and attentive.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Came for a Sunday brunch with a coupon. Waiter was on point and even allowed us to swap mimosas (which we were supposed to get) to bloody mary and boy were they good - nice and spicy.  We both ordered the chilaquiles - you're thinking tortilla chips with eggs, cheese, and some sauce - oh but this had a lot of love - may be the best chilaquiles I've had since Mr. Cream in Puerto Vallarta :) but totally different - it was almost like a casserole made a la minute - if you like chilaquiles and mexican flavors get it because it also had a delicious tomatillo sauce too. 

I loved it and we will be back.
author: Christine V.

description:
It's always fun to visit a W, and Trace got pretty good Yelp reviews, so we tried it with out-of-town friends for brunch this weekend.

In short, the menu is limited. I was looking for a good salad, but there were no salads on the menu. Of the four of us, we agreed the food was good. But not great. Service was fine.
author: Susan M.

description:
Aw i can see myself here for a girls group lunch or a date. Fabulous setting. Kind and courteous service! 
French toast was savory. Looks small at first but enough food for a lunch. 
Tuna salad was fantastic and you can taste the fresh!
Love. It is like a hidden gem. Surprised not more people know about it.
Would be even better if price was a little better or continue to offer promos. Everyone loves a good promo!

Cannot wait to share with friends
author: Veranna N.

description:
We came to TRACE as a start to our Bliss & TRACE Spa Package which has a 2-course menu with some of the regular TRACE brunch items as well other healthy choices (http://www.trace-sf.com/assets/u/BlissSpaMenu115.pdf). There are some open area tables as well as "booths" screened off a bit (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trace-san-francisco?select=XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA#UwC1B9kmdsgWMAnu7O1d8A) which is where we were seated.

What better way to start a spa day than with a Bloody Mary (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trace-san-francisco?select=XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA#XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA), though the g/f would say a Mimosa the better choice.

She started with the Market Fruit Salad (vanilla and honey straus yogurt http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trace-san-francisco?select=XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA#Gb7WosLJ5CvKJsf4eEUb5Q) which had banana, orange, apple, watermelon, pineapple, pears, and grapes. Pretty basic, it was a big plate with everything nice and ripe.

I went with the Sliced Yellowtail (green goddess, cucumber, radish, toasted almonds
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trace-san-francisco?select=XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA#8f8B3AXJ8aLTG0Tzq_xCFA). In addition to the listed ingredients there were strawberries, kumquats, and some watercress. Fresh and clean flavors. The fish was better than many sushi bars I've been to. The almonds were a great component adding crunch and flavor.

For the mains, the g/f got the Fregola Sarda "Risotto" (slow poached egg, fall mushrooms, herb salad, aged balsamic http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trace-san-francisco?select=XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA#KvHYyjsiMg7rfNTEDEAxxA). Fregola Sarda is an Italian pasta reminiscent of Israeli couscous. The egg was nicely poached and the "risotto" got a thumbs up.

I had the Grilled Albacore Tuna Salad (arugula, shaved fennel, quinoa, mixed beans, green goddess http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trace-san-francisco?select=XmS7vbY3Qp3I4oKrJPhhjA#tb_Z2G3sC7sD93tt94sSCg). Nicely seared tuna. This had a little too much going on with the green goddess on the plate plus a different dressing on the salad.

Pretty good as part of the package we got, but next time I'd go for the a la carte brunch menu, though with the hotel restaurant prices, that might not be soon.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I have been to TRACE a few times for breakfast meetings. It is in a great central location around the corner from Moscone center and a close walk from the Montgomery BART.

I think it is good for a meeting environment, but I have to admit it is a bit pricey for the food you get. I happened to think the food was average- not bad, but nothing spectacular.

But, the service is great. The staff is quick and very friendly. I do not think I would go here unless it was for a work related breakfast.
author: Umang P.

description: The best meal that I have had out in a long time. Salmon was perfect and the Brussels sprouts are a must. Halibut was flaky and moist! Excellent service! Very happy and will be back soon!
author: Kimberly R.

description:
*** I've eaten here twice and I'm a fan already. ***

1st visit on Fri nite after Yerba Buena Arts Center:
Flatbread for starter with brussel sprouts followed
by a braised pork shoulder gnocchi w/ mushrooms.
Both were quite tasty, and adequately portioned for 
a small plate selections.  I was satisfied as a result.

2nd visit came Sat @noon before walking SFMoMA:
Poached eggs & prosciutto w/ arugula on an english 
muffin smothered in hollandaise.  That was delicious.
However, fried potatoes on the side were overcooked.

Overall I like its contempo ambience and location here.
Service was exceptional over brunch ... a group effort.

*** I'd certainly ret'n.  A great spot to meet friends. ***
author: Barry W.

description: Gorgeous layout!! Located right next to the Bar inside Whotel but without the loud noise. Good list of wine choices and the servers are more than happy to give you some sample taste. Must order the liver pâté mousse!! Brussels sprouts is freaking awesome...sweet and tangy. Three of us shared the salmon with mandarin orange and chicken with snap peas/gnocchi entrees, very fulfilling. Almost forgot about the scrumptious  bread (olive, sour dough or nut/wheat) an amazing dinn experience!
author: Vee V.

description:
A fancy brunch at the W hotel means: 

1. Classy, trendy surroundings complete with a live DJ 

2. Savory-sweet bacon and cocoa nib waffle paired with a stiff bacon bourbon old fashioned 

3. A juicy Burger cooked medium topped with goat cheese and arugula and served with perfectly roasted fingerling potatoes

4. The only way to start a gorgeous Saturday in SF!
author: Janice C.

description:
Fried Brussels Sprouts are a must. Plus vegetarian. Crispy w pecan and a bit of honey. Roger our waiter is the resident beekeeper and the best waiter. 
Recommended the salmon, which I was not super excited about ordering. OMG!  The best ever crust seasoned crust and skin w a bit of ginger. 

The oysters of the day, again highly recommend by Roger were fantastic.  My husband had the pork chop, huge, tasty, and juicy.  Had a fresh corn base. 

We got a free chocolate dessert. It was my birthday. With a candle. 

Highly recommend going better than lots of other seafood places at about 1/2 the cost. 

I want to eat here everyday.
author: Terese O.

description: The food was good except the shanghai noodle. It was soaked in half in of oil. The price is over the top compares to the quality.I got Travelzoo for the deal which is $69 for 2 main courses, 1 share and 2 other side dishes. I ordered extra lemonade and lemon meringue. I ended up paid extra $48 ( service fee 20% on original price).So $69+48 total for that dinner. It wasn't exceptional. With $117 dollars, I can get better food out there in SF.
author: Michelle D.

description:
My friend picked out Trace (located in the stylish W hotel) as one of the stops in our San Francisco sojourn. We came in last Saturday night for dinner and were seated within 15 minutes after arriving. The restaurant manager and team were all very friendly, professional and courteous. 

The W San Francisco outpost hired architect Stanley Saitowitz to redesign the W's two levels (including the lobby, restaurant and two bars) and to really give it a more local San Francisco personality and feel.  His design inspiration comes from a line in Ambrose Bierce's poem "This city is a point upon a map of fog." The dark gray and purple color scheme gets lighter and cloudier as you head towards the top level and you can catch traces of many San Francisco monuments on the walls. Saitowitz steers away from commonplace themes of SF (the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars) and really captures the mysterious and edgy side of SF. The sleek and simple white vinyl-cushioned dining room (with white banquettes, vinyl placemats and sleek touches) really embodies the W brand. 

We were both very pleased with the seasonally-minded, many-layered dishes. The cuisine really mirrors the fresh, clean, stylish and sophisticated W brand. We both savored the Roasted Lamb Meatballs, a very bold-flavored starter plate featuring fresh Mediterrean ingredients like seasoned lamb, olives and mint. I had the Pan-seared Alaskan Halibut with summer beans, roasted garlic and onions and a sweet-savory grape mustarda sauce. Beautiful summer flavors with a perfectly cooked filet. 

My friend had the Flat Iron Steak with maitake mushrooms, grilled spring onions, salt roasted potatoes finished with a porcini glaze. I cannot vouch for the flavor of the steak because my friend did not offer me any. Bad friend, bad friend! Jk I can say  one thing: he left no trace (pun intended). Musta been good! 

The Trace menu includes both large plates (wild king salmon, roasted duck breast, pork tenderloin, crispy chicken and more) and small plates (lamb meatballs, seared Monterey squid, sliced yellowtail, chicken liver mousse, Pacific oysters, roasted pork belly & fontina flatbread) and some high-brow cocktails and wine.

Come in and experience this sexy and cutting-edge hotel and restaurant in SOMA.
author: Nicole D.

description:
A wonderful restaurant!  I went with my family and we ordered the corn and Brussels sprouts appetizers to start. The dishes were seasoned well, tasted delicious, and the portions were generous enough.  I would highly recommend them both. 

For dinner, I had the scallops, which were fantastic!  They paired the scallops with a subtly spicy lamb sausage - an interesting choice - and the inclusion of baby carrots, zucchini, and peppers was lovely.  The flavors were on point, and everything went well with a Riesling.

My only critique was that the restaurant was a bit loud, and the sound system seemed to be directly wired to an oldies station.  At times conversation could be difficult, but that's my only complaint. 

All and all, a great pick. I would pay another visit soon.
author: Sydney K.

description: The W Hotel is one of my favorite hotels in SF, known for throwing a wild Halloween party and hosting several fashion-related events. I've  walked by Trace before and have always wanted to give it a try. The restaurant itself reminds me of LA, very trendy with a seductive jewel-tone color palette. I'm obsessed with the terrarium light fixtures and the white fringe outlining the restaurant, adding privacy to the over-sized centric booths. I came here on a Thursday and was shocked at how quiet the W was. Trace was even more desolate with just two or three other tables occupied. I'm not complaining; scenes are wonderful to be part of, but there's a unique level of intimacy that comes from having a restaurant almost all to yourself. The service was superior. Roger is the real gem of Trace; he's attentive, personable, and knowledgeable on the menu. I can't speak highly of him enough. I was pleasantly surprised to see they offered Cakebread by the glass. I ordered a glass of sauvignon blanc and salmon rillette to start. The salmon rillette makes for a decent appetizer; it was good but not great. The whole grain mustard that comes with the rillette is what gives the dish edge. For the main course, I ordered the scallops, and that's what took Trace from a competitive three star to a four-star restaurant. If you're going to try any dish at Trace, make it the scallops. The scallops are generous in proportion and come in a sweet sauce with small shavings of apples as garnish. My boyfriend had the chicken. We were both excited to see how it paired with the bread pudding and brussel sprouts. Much like the salmon rillette, it was nice but didn't stand out. Overall Trace is a beautiful restaurant that offers unique dishes with interesting spins.
author: Leann W.

description: Both Michael Bauer and Patricia Unterman, local San Francisco food critics, reviewed Trace favorably. However, neither found the atmosphere comfortable. Keeping this in mind, we sat away from the bar area on a hopping Saturday night. We found the service excellent, the wine list good, the food quality very good, and it was comfortable. Portion sizes are large, although expensive. A satisfying meal can be constructed with a few drinks,  the share plates and appetizers. Although the Mains are prepared very well, they are standard fare: flank steak, burger, salmon, halibut, etc.
author: Sandra B.

description:
Great service -- ask for Yaya! 

They have an innovative chef and menu. June was beefless to assist in the water conservation efforts as it takes so many more gallons of water to process (fun fact on menu). 

Check it out for breakfast, lunch, client meetings, happy hour or dinner! It's also conveniently located inside the W!
author: Lourdes R.

description: I went there for lunch with my work colleagues. The ambiance is very sleek, modern and comfortable. The dishes we ordered were beautifully prepped, fresh and bursting with colors, flavors and textures. One of our favs was the Brussels Sprouts appetizer. It was so good we asked for the recipe and our server YaYa got the Chef to come over to share it with us AND brought us some of their magic hot mustard oil. The service was impeccable, and I must say I have not seen this level of attention to detail, helpfulness and genuine customer care in a long time. One of my colleagues is coming back for lunch next week, not only because of the food but also for this incredible customer experience. Thank you!
author: Alexandra D.

description:
restaurant week. I can't think of a single thing that was good about this meal. San Francisco is known for "fusion" and that's fine, but this restaurant was a sad example of not knowing what the heck you're doing and instead just mixing a bunch of ingredients together that make no sense. 
The mussels appetizer with way too much lamb and onion which drowned out all the other flavors (ironically the mussels tasted like nothing else but steamed mussels)
The fish entree which had a sauce that didn't do anything, and edamame which had no place for taste or its texture.
It is embarrassing for the W to have this restaurant inside its doors.
author: Grapes T.

description:
The experience was not as pleasant. They had a discrepancy between their Yelp menu and real menu. 

My husband brought a bunch of students there and it was obviously too much for the students to afford. 

We talked to the manager afterwards. The lady was rather rude. She turned the issue around and claimed that we could have walked out of the place when we saw the difference. 

Sigh..
author: Susan H.

description: I tried Trace for the 1st time for a family dinner with my brother and his partner-  the service was gracious and thoughtful.  The room was elegant and fun. To name a few of the excellent staff- starting with Beto the host, Ciera our knowledgeable waiter, Pat making sure the table is perfect and Christopher stopping by to say hello and making us feel very welcome.  We decided to have the tasting menu and really everything was amazing- we truly appreciated the Chef's efforts!  I will definitely be back to enjoy another experience at Trace.
author: Patrick V.

description:
Ultra chic, ultra modern, but a pretty average/ below average brunch experience. 

I came here with my roommate after purchasing the Gilt City deal and was wholly disappointed with the experience. 

First up was the mimosa that came with the Gilt "Energize Breakfast." It was terrible. How do you serve up a bad mimosa? Maybe it was the juice they used, but it definitely was a strange clash between oddly sour and unpleasantly bitter.

Second was the coffee. 
My first cup was sour. Usually, if it's my first cup of coffee for the day I down it before it even gets a chance to hit the taste buds. This cup was so bad though, that I had to ask them to bring me a second cup.  I felt like "that annoying customer" doing it, but how do you even make sour coffee? (It wasn't the milk) Second time around, the coffee was better, but at $4 a cup, you'd think they would get it right the first time.

Then came the fresh squeezed juices. I ordered the kale, celery, parsley, etc. juice and my roommate order the chai "juice". Both were pretty good. As a raging Pressed Juicery fan, I would equate the Chai to one of the almond milks and the kale one to one of Pressed Juicery's green drinks.  To be honest though, Pressed Juicery is a LOT better in terms of taste.

Then came the meals- my roommate ordered the vegetarian hash and I ordered the proscuitto benedict. This is where I was most impressed. The hash was average, yet still managed to convinced me that if I were a vegetarian and all dishes tasted like TRACE's vegetarian hash, that I wouldn't die.  The benedict was especially worthwhile.  The egg was poached perfectly and complimented by a wonderful hollandaise sauce that was tinged with the perfect amount of citrus flavor. The home fries were clear winners here- perfectly seasoned, crispy on the outside, soft on the inside.

Overall, I wouldn't come back here again, but if you do find yourself in this establishment, I would go ahead and skip straight to the meals and pass on the mimosas, juices, etc. They aren't worth your while.
author: Patricia K.

description: Our waiter Roger was excellent.  He's also the bee keeper for the restaurant.  The food was amazing.  Ambiance was sheik modern and romantic.  Very sex in the city type of look. Will be back for those amazing Mashed potatoes!
author: PlainJane F.

description: A dine about town success! Roger took care of us, and we were very impressed with the service, the food, the drink, and I for one enjoyed the modern styling/ club like design while still being able to hear each other talk. Definitely seems like a great place to go to for dinner before a night on the town!
author: Greg F.

description:
Hotel brunches can be questionable at times, because I never know whether the food will just be average or more. Luckily, a Gilt City promotion tempted me to check out TRACE at the W Hotel.

We began our morning walking into the ultra-chic, modern restaurant with upbeat music playing in the background. The epitome of trendy? I think so. San Francisco? Not so much. It actually reminded me a lot quintessential trendiness at SoCal restaurants. 

Regardless, the food at TRACE was great. After ordering our libations (mimosas were our choice), we proceeded on to main entrees for which I chose the Eggs Chilaquiles. Pretty delicious, I must say! The cotija cheese was so, so fresh and a great topping to the dish. 

The portion sizes were quite large for a hotel restaurant, so rest assured that you're definitely not overpaying. The $14 dish was worth its price tag. I'd return to TRACE again, even without the Gilt City voucher.
author: Mansi A.

description:
I only have the faintest recollection of what XYZ was like as a dining destination a decade ago since I was probably not trendy enough to hang out at the W Hotel. Back then, I was closer to a 'P' than a 'W'... OK, maybe an 'S' but surely not a 'W'. A lot of years have passed and a lot of rings have grown around my trunk, so I must surely be past 'W' by now. Sparked by a couple of positive reviewers by Yelpers I could trust, I decided to give it a try with a longtime friend of mine, but now it's been redone into Trace. Trace? Like "he left the crime scene without a..."? Gee, that's so hip I don't get it.

What I do get is that they use all the right buzzwords on their website - "socially responsible", "sustainable", and the ever-popular "locally sourced". And the entrees are described as "Farmed", "Crafted", or "Shared". So San Francisco. Michael Bauer was none too impressed with the food he had there last month according to his Chronicle review, chiding its "uncomfortable surroundings" and uneven execution. My friend and I didn't have the same experience as we pretty much liked the place. Sure, the decor felt like an West Elm catalog spread, but the food was quite good and creatively prepared.

As a working mother of two and wife of a burgeoning car-wash magnate, my friend Liz deserved the pleasures to be had with the $15 Anson Mills Farro Verde, which was a delicately delicious mix of melty farro, cavolo nero, delicata squash, crispy ginger bits, and best of all, Brussel sprouts. Mine was the "Crafted" selection - the $13 Braised Niman Ranch Pork Shoulder, which was a nice meat-falling-off-the-bone delight piled on some pan-crisped gnocchi and accompanied by hen-of-the-wood mushrooms and pecorino cheese (see photo). Even Bauer liked it, and I would definitely order that again.

FOOD - 4 stars...liked the creations despite the pretensions
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...like I said, West Elm...dark chocolate woods, blinding white chairs
SERVICE - 3 stars...attentive enough
TOTAL - 4 stars...guess I have to be farmed and shared next time since I was crafted this time
author: Ed U.

description:
Date & Time:  Thursday December 1, 2011 @ Noon
Location:  Former XYZ in The W Hotel
Dining Companion:  Dana
Crowd:  Suits & W Guests-  Ladies in Sweaters, Leggings & Thigh High Louboutin Boots 
Music:  Holiday Music & Foster the People 
Decor:  Mod White Interior.  Sleek Bar & Furnishings
Service:  Friendly 
Imbibe:  Full Bar
Devour:  Pork Belly FlatBread, Trace Burger & HazelNut Panna Cotta
Total:  $45.46
author: Genevieve Y.

description: We had dinner reservations at Trace last Saturday night at 6 pm, after we saw Into The Woods at the Golden Gate Theater.  We arrived early at 5:30 pm, and ordered the Rum Ice Tea (and the non-alcoholic type) with sweet potato fries at the bar, because we were starving for food.  We were taken to our street view table at 6 pm, where we were most graciously hosted by our waiter, "The Bee Keeper".  Our conversation with him totally enhanced our dining experience.  He was the ideal waiter!  A terrific host!  We both ordered the Hangar Steak, which was sliced in pieces, and was very tasty.  We shared dessert over coffees, and just lingered there until 7:45 pm, with no rush put upon by our waiter.  The rest rooms are communal with toilet areas as large as small apartments.  We and another couple got a chuckle over this in the rest room.  When we left, there were plenty of people in the "W" Hotel bar, where Trace is located, and there was music in the balcony bar.  Just a terrific place to hang out, made even more special by our "bee keeper" waiter.  Although we live in the East Bay, we are mulling over an overnight stay at the "W" Hotel, which is just down the street from the SF MOMA, Yerba Buena Center, Museum and park, and the Jewish Contemporary Museum.
author: Howard S.

description:
This is a very cute place to lunch. I came here during work and ordered the seasonal soup, which was pumpkin with creme fraiche and mexican chocolate drizzled on top. it was the perfect amount of soup and great flavor!

The prices are pricey, but come expecting that. When I checked in, there was a free share plate with the purchase of 2 entrees. I did not use it, but I plan to!

Decor is very trendy chic - light and fun. The window seats are great, and there are semi private booths if a more intimate atmosphere is desired. 

I can't wait to come back here.
author: Kailey O.

description:
Start with the rose champaigne for $16 per glass and roll into the Rose from Provence for $12 per glass.  Both paired perfectly with the Brussels Sprouts, Kale Salad, Salmon and Crab over polenta. Absolutely perfect night out with my wife. Shawn was our server and he helped steer us in the right direction. I loved the bread but would love it more if it was warm. Great ambiance but you have to love DJ based music. I loved it... Very ecliptic/diverse. 
Highly recommend Trace (focused on sustainability and tracing foods roots back to its origins)....
author: Aaron G.

description:
A lot has changed since XYZ closed down. when the W first opened, the restaurant and bar scene were hot for quite a while. As time moved on it was no longer a destination, and i think the management has recognized that.
