Sleeker, darker and more contemporary, Trace has undergone a transformation in it's aesthetics, food and bar program. The space certainly looks more club-lounge like. Stark white tables with patterened mercury colored matts, large black perforated dividers with sheer mercury curtains allow them to break up the space. There's a very long communal table in the back with a matching long bar on the second floor with various lounge booths.

After being promptly seated by the attractive hostesses, we perused the drink menus. Now most (if not all) the W's in Manhattan are designed by one Randy Gerber (Mr Cindy Crawford) and his rep and the fact that it's NYC causes cocktail prices to be at a certain level. The fact we're in the W here also carries some rep and at $14 a pop theyre not the cheapest. However my Bourbon based Mr Robinson was excellent and well worth the price. It was a good start. After perusing the menu, we saw that they are following the farm to table ethos that most of SF is championing and that's good to see from a national hotel chain. We ended up with:

-BRAISED PORK SHOULDER
crisp gnocchi, pecorino
-CHICKEN "OYSTER" TORTELLINI
roast chicken broth, pickled cherry peppers
-PAN ROASTED DUCK BREAST
savoy spinach, pine nuts, wine grapes, black barley, quinoa
-BAKED CALIFORNIA SEABAKED SEA BASS
fresh shelling beans, cippolinis, broccoli spigarello, fennel sausage
-PANNA COTTA
thyme, apples, tuille
-PEACH CRUMBLE
white wine sauce

Now i like XYZ's food when it debuted, but it wasn't widely memorable. I'm liking the fact that they're letting the chef do his food and it's definitely an upgrade. Everything was tasting with solid flavor profile combinations. I'd say my only complaint was the duck breast was over on temperature. The staff were quite attentive. Roger our server was in tune with us, our waters were never below half full and we were certainly well taken care of. They were smart to open on a holiday weekend and when we arrived there were a handful of folks. but by 9.30 the place was mostly full for a Monday night. Go figure. They maybe hammered when the next weekend rolls around, but if they can keep this level up, it will be definitely worth returning for both food and drink. 4.25 stars.
author: Kim N.

description:
Had a number of meals during my recent stay at the w San Fran. Like the hotel trace occupies - the Resturant tries to hard to be different - odd and out of the box- the hotels rates a poor 3 star hotel. The Resturant does have some good food- some wait staff are attentive - however most of the female staff are racist rude and arrogant . If your stuck at the hotel and you can't leave to find a better cheaper more suitable option. Then expect to pay more than it's worth - eat something odd- fusions you wouldn't expect or frankly consider.
Breakfast is I have to say sensational. And would rate a good four stars. But lunch and dinner are a disappointment - especially when you get the bill.
author: Craig G.

description:
Can't say I have had a better brunch meal in a long time, period. And I have high standards. 

Used the travelzoo deal, 2 brunch + 2 mimosas for basically half off. You do pay auto-18% gratuity onsite, but it is worth it. 

lady and I both had the steak and eggs. BOMB. phenomenal. Huge 8-10oz steak, two scrambled eggs, potatoes. Just absolutely perfectly prepared. Big meal, She would have taken leftovers if we lived local. 

service was decent, good. 
the Hotel and restaurant are typical trendy upscale clean awesome W style, love it. 

Would recommend, and go back in an instant if in town.
author: Tommy K.

description:
Appetizers and Drinks!!

I had the Bone Marrow which was ok, nothing special!

The Oysters & Mussels were definitely a Hit!!
author: Prem K.

description:
I felt very lucky when I got here.  The parking was in downtown San Francisco, and I actually scored a spot right next to the restaurant and I swear it was the only 'free' spot in the city.  The restaurant doesn't validate, so just be aware of that when you go.  However, parking aside, which I would guess could be difficult in a rush, it is WELL worth the visit.  This is one of the best restaurants I have been to.  The food was phenomenal.  

It started out with fried brussel spouts with pecans, an heirloom tomato salad, which was fantastic.  I had chicken, which was beautifully prepared and delicous.   My companion had the duck, which was also wonderful (I tried some).  I ordered a glass of wine and didn't think to get the strawberry basil lemonade like my friend did.  Boy, as soon as I tried that, I wanted a glass of it as well.  

The wine was high quality, but don't dis the non-alcoholic fare.  Well worth the money.  

Don't pass this one up, go to it if you have the chance, they are amazing.
author: Heidi F.

description: Its a Great place to have Dinner  Ray is so Friendly and have a Great Personality !!! He makes you feel at home ... He always check on us if we're doing fine... I highly recommend this Place
author: Ron M.

description:
We had a great dining experience here at Trace when we were visiting the other week.

The restaurant is hip and fancy at the same time.  I wish I could remember the name of our server, but he was great.  He had a great personality and took great care of us as well!

We started out with the chicken liver pate and it was perfect.  We kept running out of crackers and our waiter, being the awesome guy that he is, kept casually sliding some off a little plate for us :)

We both had the rib eye, which was great.  We had pureed potatoes on the side, but I would've preferred regular mashed potatoes.  The puree just didn't do it for me.

I'm confused by a lot of people's complaints that it's too expensive.  It seems to be a comparable price to other restaurants for the quality you get.  It's not a Denny's, folks...
author: Ella M.

description:
Bottom line: Great bars in the area make it hard to suggest Trace

My friends and I went to Trace for TBT or the Q102 sponsored event every Thursday that plays "Old School" (90s 00s hip hop) music. The music was great! There were 5 of us and we had a very good time but the fun was more due the company than the venue itself. 

The drinks and food were at 90s prices* but the prices are high and drinks less than average that it does not feel like deal at all. Side note, the burger is $19... which is the same price on their normal bar menu. The previous night, I went to a happy hour and got a very good cocktail for $8 and at Trace I got a subpar $8 cocktail. Pretty disappointing. *Hotels do charge more than the average bar so yes, the prices are discounted but the quality should be much higher.

To my surprise, the service was actually very very good. Very attentive waiters came to our lounge area so we didn't have go to the bar. The bar seemed organized and seemed like you didn't have to wait to get a drink.

Overall, with so many cool and fun bars on Howard and on alleys nearby it is hard to make a case for Trace.
author: Matthew T.

description:
Great Place!  Being in the wine business it's crucial to take clients out and wine and dine them.  Priya was awesome in accommodating our party and gave us spit buckets etc so we could taste wines with our dinner guests.  The Service? Impeccable!  Roger was awesome, best service I've had in a long time!  Food was perfect, bee hives on the 24th floor-just pretty much as cool as it gets
Thank you!
author: Michelle J.

description:
Decor: Monochromatic, looks like HGTV made it over for $500, and frankly unappetizing. 
Food: Olives - good. Lots. Can't screw up olives that much. Salmon - tasty, needed more vegetables, bit overcooked. Beet salad - good but beets were underdone, there wasn't enough burrata and the overall portion was small. 
Drinks: Ice tea was good - free refills. Woopdido.
Service: Excellent.
So, why the 2 stars? I've experienced better AND cheaper. For the above it was over $70 w/ tip. Too spendy for lunch. Too spendy for the amount of food.
author: Mi M.

description:
Stayed at the W and after walking around town all day we decided to stay in and eat at Trace.  

I am NOT a foodie, don't like things that are fancy for no reason and I am really not into gourmet ANYTHING.  I have basic taste and I know what I like.  So when the hostess placed this small one page menu in front of me I thought "Crap! We're gonna have to find another place to eat." Well, I was wrong.  Most of the menu consisted of seafood, which I don't eat but I did spy the fried Brussels sprouts with sweet and sour mustard seeds and pecans.  Ok. I also noticed the roasted beet salad. Ok.  Nothing else on the menu appealed to me in the least bit. So fried Brussels sprouts and beet salad it was.  

The food was DELICIOUS!!! The honey used on the beet salad is produced by the hives located on the roof of the hotel and maintained by a couple of the restaurant staff.  I thought that was very cool. 

I will say the service was very slow but our waiter was nice and made up for the delays with a free dessert. So that was a cool.  

The overall effect of the restaurant said upscale/classy.  The décor was sophisticated without being stuffy.  I appreciated that.
author: Ayanna H.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience here...

Chicken Liver Moose - amazing, so good!  A rich and decadent way to start a meal...the liver was savory and creamy....it arrived with a nice jam/compote that was sweet and went perfectly with the liver.

Crispy Fried Chicken - this was a nice dish - pieces of fried chicken breast served with potato puree, mushrooms and broccolini.  It wasn't what I expected, but it was very good - it was nice to have fried chicken without having to deal with bones.  

The ambiance was cool and trendy and service was friendly and attentive.  I would definitely come back here...I'd love to try the brunch options since those seem to be amazing.
author: Ken G.

description:
Excellent!! I generally do not eat at my hotel because I like to get out and explore but after a long day I gave Trace a Shot. I had the Scallops and the Chocolate cake which was amazing.

My waiter Roger was one of the best I have had in a while, honest opinion and really efficient.

I will be back
author: Dave T.

description: Best eggs (sunny side up) I've ever eaten. Not to mention, the perfect place to chat with clients.
author: Billy S.

description:
Came here after going to the SF MOMA closing celebrations. 

The vibe is hip - the music is like Ulrich Schnauss with plenty of well dressed people out to enjoy a nice evening. The place is clean and the service is good.

The food isn't bad either - got the yellowtail sashimi, scallops, and short ribs. Washed it down with a Dark and Stormy.

I wouldn't say the food is out of this world amazing and I probably wouldn't dine here again unless the opportunity came up but it's not a bad option. Slightly on the expensive side however.

Come here for a drink or happy hour, not dinner.
author: Julia P.

description:
I went in with no real sense of the restaurant--I was meeting colleagues--we were in town from Boston and New York--and I was not involved in the selection of the restaurant. 

Amazing food. Ingredients are fresh and the food is so delicious.  The crab lettuce rolls were best dish I had during my visit to SF (which included meals at Zuni cafe and Gary danko). The Brussel sprouts were delicious an the sliced steak was lean, perfectly seasoned and served with the most delightful side of fluffy, buttery, whipped mashed potatoes. 

The service was efficient and friendly. I will definitely go back on my next trip to SF.
author: Laura S.

description:
http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FWI28-fc7aBThUlCVOzjeQ/l.jpg

You will get this for $50. + tax & tips.   mm meh. I've experienced better.
author: Jee C.

description:
Absolutely loved their lunch. With my yelp check in I got a free appetizer, amazing considering that's $16 free! 

Their $2 drink special was wonderful, highly recommend the lemongrass martini, just sweet enough and not watered down as I thought it would be considering the price.

I got the chicken sandwich with jalapeño aoli which was very good but I think it would've been better if the bread had been toasted. My coworker got the steak which was cooked beautifully and the chorizo sauce on it was incredible.
author: Grace P.

description:
this review is strictly for the staff of Trace @ the W.

On 1/9/13 yelp and trace held a  YEE.  This event was probably a a tad overbooked, which is always a risky proposition, but the pros at Trace seemed unphased, they dodged the lines, and the ravaged mobs - attacking the trays of appetizers, like - nothing short of -  seasoned ninjas. 


Food, beverage, and bussing was simply world class.  The staff that worked the yelp event on Weds Jan 9, '13, all deserve a bonus and a raise for a job truly well done (in way less than favorable conditions. I've seen lesser men crumble under the pressure of an overbooked YEE, and break down in tears).

Trace chefs and mixoligists, likewise did not dissapoint - everything was on time and delicious from drinks to bites a job truly well done.

Finally the event itself - Jessica and Jon - a job truy well done! As ive stated before - a bit overcrowded for the venue, but stil an event to remember - good time was had by all (especially yours truly).
author: Oleg H.

description:
Love the modern Ambiance!! The food was really good- I ordered the beet salad... beets, burrata and fresh greens with a drizzle of their home made honey. That's right- this hotel has it's own bees nest up on the roof!!
Had the NY strip. Was WAY too salty which was a shame because the dish had such potential. 
All in All though definitely a neat place to check out.
author: Allie P.

description:
Amazing food with service and management to match! We had a college dinner for 21 with a coursed out menu. As we were all aspiring hospitality and restaurant managers, Rocio as well as the Executive Sous Chef were amazing enough to even tour us around the facility. Everything is made fresh and to order. It reflects in the flavor of the food.

If we are ever back in town, we'll be sure to drop by again!
author: Frederick V.

description: This is a review for breakfast while staying at the W Hotel.  It was really excellent (though pricey).  Super high quality, fast service, excellent coffee, wonderful service.  Everything was perfectly cooked.  Good place for a business breakfast as well as fairly quiet and spacious.
author: Tami H.

description:
Lunch review

-expensive? but then again, its a trendy hotel restaurant
-small portions... practically rabbit food
-left really hungry and contemplated grabbing a cheeseburger on the way home
-took the server 10-15 minutes to refill my water glass

I had the salad and yellowtail, while my friend had the risotto.
Came to about $65.00 w/tip
author: Angelica C.

description:
Very colse to Moscone center, but sometime is better walk and go away..
BTW my friend has ordered a dish with tuna and they have given to him other fish (after claim it was changed). my chicken sandwich was too spicy.
Good atmosphere and nice people that up the score. Maybe too noisy for me...
author: Max G.

description:
I had a rose petal cocktail and a creme brulee. The rose petal cocktai consisted of stoli cranberry vodka, cointreau, cranberry juice, lemon, and schramsberg brut. I love cocktails and sweet drinks, but this drink just tasted like sugar, watered down vodka, and ice. For $15, I expect a little kick for my drink, but sadly I was disappointed.
The creme brulee was fine--nothing just exciting, but a lot of creme for the plate. If I weren't staying at the W, and actually decided to get off my butt, I would go somewhere else.
There is seating upstairs, and you can just sit anywhere at nighttime and someone will come to serve you.
author: Michele L.

description:
Tried this restaurant at the W with a group of friends who suggested it.

The service was mixed. The man who brought us bread and beverages, I did not care for. He was just a little abrupt, possibly seemed a little cranky. The waiter, however, was excellent and personable.

The food was decent. Not mind-blowingly good, but decent. The bill came out to a little over $50 per person. At that point, the meal didn't seem so good! It was alright, but overpriced for what it was.

The vibe was weird. Ultra-modern and a little gaudy in decor, but the place was almost completely empty--on a Saturday night! 

I really want to give this either 2 or 3 stars... It wasn't at all a bad experience, and the food was decent, but I'm not likely to go back.
author: J K.

description:
Let me first say-- the service here was TOP NOTCH.  From being seated, to getting water, and just overall attentiveness-- they deliver.
Unfortunately.. the food doesn't back it up.  The appetizers (first course)-- Beet Salad was amazing, and the Brussel Sprouts were really delicious.
The main course was the big let down.  I got the pasta with mushrooms and truffle, topped by a poached egg. 
The egg was overdone, so from the start, the breaking/ and "ooey-gooey" part really never happened, and this dish NEEDED that for "sauce."  The mushrooms and truffle were overdone, and the pasta was a little mushy too.  It just didn't taste good.
Dessert was OK, but nothing special, and way too much in terms of portion size.
author: Kelly C.

description: Was able to book a last minute lunch for 8 people. I've eaten here 3 times and the food is fantastic. The 'On the fly' lunch is especially a great deal. I had the cauliflower soup, a chicken sandwich on an acme roll with home made pickles and a mini ice cream sandwich for dessert. Everything was perfect including our fantastic server Damien. While the W isn't quite the hip place it once was, TRACE is definitely keeping up with the times. Now just remodeling those darn outdated hotel rooms!
author: Karlyn N.

description:
Super meat-markety and expensive. I was bummed by the food - even though I thought it sounded really awesome (lamb gnocchi). And unfortunately it didn't really agree with me (eek).

The drinks were fine, but had actually too much alcohol (learn to mix in the right ratio Mr. Bartender). And I was surrounded by drunk people no matter which side of the bar I switched too.

Oh well. Not the end of the world, but not sure I'll be back any time soon.
author: Joshua B.

description: Came to Trace for a Special food truck event with The Chairman food truck so I can't speak for the regular restaurant but the food truck event was great. Was able to try some great food and had some good drinks and cocktails at the same time. We had a ton of apps and it was a 12 course meal so definitely worth the $40 admission charge for the event. They do these events about once a month so keep an eye out for it and come out next time. The service was a little slow but it was a full house with only 1 seating so that could be why.  Everyone was friendly and since it was a special night for us they hooked us up with a dessert, special message and a card from the staff. Overall a great night out. Keep up the good work.
author: Vincent W.

description:
We would definitely come back here again. My wife and I had dinner here when we were in SF celebrating our 20th anniversary. I had the scallops, which are easy to screw up (if you cook them too long, they become a rubbery mess not worth eating -- and certainly not at these prices). They were cooked to melt-in-your-mouth perfection, and the carrots, peppers and squash were excellent additions. The sausage was mild and added a nice change of texture and taste to the dish.

My wife had the Roasted Cauliflower and found the vegetables well seasoned and delicious. 

They surprised us at the end with raspberry and mango sorbet (my dairy allergy is a PITA) on the house because of our celebration. The rest of the desserts looked amazing, too.

The staff were exceptionally friendly and helpful throughout the entire meal. A great experience we would highly recommend.
author: Frank A.

description:
We went here on Friday as part of San Francisco's Restaurant week.  My sis in law chose it as it would have been out of our price range normally.
The selection suited everyone's palate, vegetarians & carnivores alike.  
The food was amazing, in particular, the mushroom tagliatelle, in my opinion!  My beet salad was so good with the creamy and smooth barrata, I would have personally chosen walnuts over pistachios for the salad to provide a little more of an interesting flavour.
All the deserts were amazing, the rice pudding was sumptious and the ice cream biscuits looked like huge Oreo cookies, very tasty!
The service was great, wine o.k, though as usual that bumped up the bill.
author: Sarah W.

description: I truly don't understand how this place only has 3 1/2 stars. Everything was so amazing. My brother and I came here for restaurant week. Amazing way to try new restaurants. Started with the fried brussel sprouts and mussels. Let me tell you, I love brussel sprouts but these were the most amazing brussel sprouts I've ever had. The sauce they put on top was so delicious. My brother loved the mussels as well. I got the salmon and devoured every bite. It came with a perfectly spiced asian themed rub. For dessert I had the chocolate sea salt ice cream sandwiches. Again, so delicious. I will absolutely be back again outside of restaurant week. We were both blown away.
author: Sakina C.

description:
Attended the Yelp Elite event.

First, I want to say how AMAZING the staff are here. I've seen many people who are staffing Yelp Elite events crack under the pressure of our masses, but these guys were professional and with a smile the ENTIRE TIME. I did not see a dish sit for more then seconds when emptied and I didn't see a staff without a smile. Really Amazing!

The food was wonderful, the Crispy Berkshire Pork Belly being my favorite, tender and crispy all at the same time with a smokey flavor punch to die for.

Another favorite was the Lamb Shoulder and Mini Cobb Salad. 

The tasty bites had me longing for more and I can't wait to bring my boyfriend, J here for date night! 

Thank you to Trace for allowing Yelp Elite to take over for a night!
author: Meghan L.

description:
PROS
- Ambiance is on-point: hip, trendy, and conducive to conversation
- Attentive waiters, didn't need to ask for water refills
- Yummy bread selection to start (sourdough, green olive and nut)
- The odd menu items are conversation starters in themselves
- Visually appealing culinary presentation 

CONS
- Quail appetizer was tiny (no surprise here) and like a less delectable version of chicken
author: Stephanie T.

description: Had a reservation a month in advance for a business meeting. They called the week before to say they had a buy out. Can not recommend booking with them unless you are making a day of reservation.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Had brunch with a few girlfriends as one of them purchased the Travelzoo deal. The Travelzoo deal was only good for the Bruch Pairing ($26). 

The menu offered the following:
ZICO COCONUT WATER 6
+
CHOICE OF BREAKFAST ENTRÉE & COCKTAIL
BLOODY MARY PIZZA
crushed tomatoes, celery, pickled carrots
fresh horseradish, arugula, slow egg 15
TRACE BLOODY MARY 10
or
BACON & COCOA NIB WAFFLE
whipped cream, applewood smoked bacon 15
BACON BOURBON OLD FASHIONED 10
or
"STEAK & EGGS"
grilled brandt farms flat iron steak
charred tomatoes, béarnaise 19
"DARK AND FOGGY" 8
or
HUCKLEBERRY PANCAKESHUCKLEBERRY PANCAKES
house made ricotta, maple syrup 15
PEACH LEMONADE 11
S I D E S
danish, croissant, muffin 6
bagels, white, wheat, rye, sourdough toast 4
biscuit-softened butter with hunt lane honey 5
applewood smoked bacon 6
chicken apple sausage 6
griddled ham 6
yukon gold potatoes 4
fruit cup 6

The brunch came with coconut water. In addition, the entree also was paired with cocktails.  However, if you're not a drinker, you had the option to switch it with coffee (for example).  This worked out great since one of the friend's is preggo.  We all switched our drinks, I ordered a regular coffee, one friend ordered an orange juice, and the other two girls ordered a decaf latte.  

Three of us ordered the Bacon & Cocoa Nib Waffle.  It sounded good on the menu, but when it arrived, we were disappointed.  The waffle wasn't crispy and it came out cold.  The other friend ordered the Steak & Eggs.  She was the only that finished her dish. 

The wait time for the food was average.  What I didn't understand was why there was a wait for our drinks to come.  When our food came, our drinks were still nowhere in sight.  We tried to flag our sever, but she was too busy chatting away.  Finally, we had to ask another server where our drinks were as that should have been served first.  (minus a star)  

Overall, the service was decent and the food was just mediocre.
author: Candice H.

description:
I purchased a Gilt City 3 course meal for two at least six months ago for Trace. Life got busy so I was not able to make it until last week, right before the deal expired. On my way over there I was reading the reviews and getting a little concerned that it would not be that great...

My boyfriend and I had 7:30PM reservations on a Thursday night and there were only a few people inside, which worried me even more. We were promptly seated and served water and bread. We decided to just get 6 different things and share...and everything was REALLY GOOD.

Brussels sprouts and cauliflower soup to start, both very tasty and big portions.
Chicken confit and salmon for the entree, again both tasty and big portions.
Ice Cream Sandwiches and Carrot Cake for dessert. We actually took the cake home because we were so full and only ate one ice cream sandwich eat...but it was amazing!

Service was great, food was awesome, portions were huge....but still not sure I'd come here for a $35 a plate dinner. If I see a deal again I will be coming back though.
author: Anne K.

description: The service here is THE BEST!!!!!! Ciara is awesome at her job! We tried a sampling menu and I barley told her what I like and she nailed every dish!! A total of 9 yes 9 plates were given to me and my husband. I thought they would be small portions since its just a sampling dish but they completely filled us up! The brussel sprouts are to die for!!!!! Best thing I have eaten in a long time from a restaurant! Love the ambiance of the atmosphere. Food was delivered fast. We were seated right away and was offered a booth or table by the window which was awesome. I would definitely come back again and recommend this place to any one who wants really good food! Everything I ate was SOOOOO GOOOOODD!!! I do no eat sea food but was given the noodles which had shrimp in them and I did not even notice I was eating it because the flavors and texture are so delicious!! Also the olive bread is GREAT!!.
author: Cristina A.

description:
The food is good 
The service is excellent ask for Roger he knows his craft well !!!
Super nice guy
author: Darryl M.

description:
I got a pork shoulder entree from here that still makes me feel guilty. It was that good!  I ordered the Trace burger at first, since that is always considered their trademark speciality, but when my neighboring table got the pork shoulder, I just had to ask them what it was that they got.  I promptly changed my order and boy, am I glad I did.

Honestly, it was the best lunch I had in San Fran and that was on my last day right before my plane was about to leave. lol!  I was so happy that I had a few extra minutes to spare and sit down to grab a bite. With the large windows and great location inside the W, but a bit tucked away from the bar, it's a great spot for lunch for sure.
author: Elsa M.

description: Wow...who knew!?  A hotel restaurant that actually serves stellar food.  The Shigoku oysters were out of this world.  These were new to me...apparently they are grown in such a way as to make them bulbous and meaty in a way I've never seen before.  Served on the half shell with a jalapeño vinaigrette makes for a superb treat!  Followed by expertly prepared bone marrow and a dish of perfect scallops on a bed of corn and cauliflower made this a truly memorable meal!
author: Howard B.

description:
Trace is the definition of the modern sleek ''n' chic lounge--dark, hip and gooooorgeous, filled with beautiful people in beautiful clothing sipping beautiful drinks. It's the kind of place you'd see on Sex and the City. The decor is stunning, with strategically placed lights, sparkling fixtures and plush seating. The space is very well organized into places where you can stand, places where you can stand and eat (high tables), places you can sit and eat (4-seater tables) and places you can...well....lounge (sofas). The cocktails are really tasty and the bartenders definitely know their stuff. I especially liked the guy on the second floor, who wasn't above slipping me some extra wine :D. I also want to note that their lamb gnocchi is divine.

TIP: The bottom (first) floor is definitely the more "active" of the two floors, so stay there if you want to dance or mingle. If what you want is to be able to plop down on a comfy chair and not get up for hours, then get to Trace early, head upstairs to the second floor, and secure one of the balcony-side lounge sofas, which can easily seat a party of 6.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Stayed a the W for a conference, and decided to try out the downstairs restaurant for a brunch before our flight out.

Definitely swanky with large windows and modern decor.  The food was OK - definitely not a wide selection but choice dishes including an eggs benedict and ricotta pancakes.

I would say the service was just OK - our waiter was nice enough - but there was a definitely lack of attention to detail:

1) I ordered the "huckleberry ricotta pancakes" which appeared to be a "special" for the morning.  What I got appeared to be french toast.  I flagged down a server (not our waiter, so not really his fault, though I would have appreciated getting the order right the first time) and asked her if these were the "huckleberry ricotta pancakes" to which she waved me off with a "yes yes."  Dumb question?  Sorry.  Except after I had eaten most of it, I asked my waiter as he was clearing the table, and he was like, "those are clearly not pancakes."  Thank you.  I had gotten the "huckleberry french toast" (which I don't recall even seeing on the menu).  Thanks.  There was no offer to take it off the bill.

2) I ordered a side of bacon to my french toast/pancakes.  My friend ordered a side of fruit with her eggs benedict.  We got neither.  Oh, and we got charged, so we had to send the bill back.

3) My husband's granola with fruit ended up coming with what appeared to be a single sliced up banana and apple.  Seriously?  He had seen another patron's granola the day before, heaping with strawberries and grapefruit.  Seriously?  What a disappointment that a meal can differ so much in quality from day to day.

All in all, the food was just OK and the service a little lacking.  Everyone was perfectly nice, but I really just expected more from a restaurant of the W.  (I do want to note that our experience at the HOTEL was awesome, so this review definitely only applies to TRACE).
author: Vicki C.

description:
the place is beautiful, the service is good, as well as the food... 
avoid desserts...
it's ok to there once in while, but for dinner is too pricey
author: Andrea M.

description:
You know a restaurant is hurting when upon entering, the perky hostess asks, "Are you staying with us here at the hotel?" and she is surprised that you answer "No, we are actually from here." 

Trace has that "hotel restaurant" feeling that is hard to shake.  Über modern, white leather seats and white silestone tables with chilewich place mats make for a sterile environment that screams hotel dining in the year 2000.  The wooden menu holders are supposed to underscore the homey mantra of "farmed, foraged, crafted, and shared," but in reality they are just incongruous elements in the stark dining room.

Unimaginative, the menu does not feature anything diners in The City have not already seen.  Pickled beet salad was good, but nothing new.  Sweet and tender, seared scallops on a bed of celery root puree was not innovative either.

The overpowering scent of lilies wafting halfway across the dining room made it hard to appreciate the food and wine, and salt and pepper were conspicuously missing from the table.  Service was ham-handed at best:  the waiter carried water and wine glasses in his hand, not on a tray; dishes arrived at an irregular pace, and used plates were not cleared immediately.

Despite a few bargains (for example, 2009 Justin Cabernet Sauvignon for $60), the wine list is over-priced, listing a Veuve Clicquot (orange label) for $120.  While low on value, the list is high on diversity, featuring at least 15 wines by glass with four on tap.  

The food at Trace was good, but not great, leaving the dining room nearly empty at 7:00 on a Saturday night.  With the myriad of great choices available in The City, Trace is a good option if you are an out-of-towner staying in the hotel, but not if you live in San Francisco.
author: CJ G.

description:
It was only a matter of time before I was going to give this place a shot. Honestly, I had an overall good experience but I just didn't get that special wow factor. The ambiance is perfect --- trendy and hip the way I like it. Depending on where you sit you can be isolated from the world or you can enjoy people watching if you sit near at the window. The lighting give me the feeling of upscale-ish dining in an underground party like environment.

Their service was great. Typical service you would get at a high end type restaurant. You ask for a knife and you get a knife brought to you on a silver platter. My water was just about refilled after every two sips.

I ordered the pan roasted duck breast. Great presentation. I was hoping it was going to taste so good that I would quack but it was just mediocre. The California asparagus accompanied my duck and it was decent at best --- a bit bland.

Like I said, no wow factor. I'll stick to the bar/lounge area of the W and will venture off by foot next time I'm back in the Bay Area.
author: Xerxes N.

description: i like Trace. it's a good, versatile eating spot for any type of meal; good spot for happy hour after work, late night get-together, intimate enough for a date, perfect for a business meeting right across from Moscone. the food is very good, not great, but i like the price-point compared to other similar restaurants, and the service each time i've gone has been terrific. if you're staying at the W, it's pretty much a must-stop at least once.
author: Mike C.

description:
Trace = fresh and delicious Ingredients from traceable sources.  

Trace = a fine menu with MANY vegetarian-friendly options.

Trace = cool decor accents that come from sustainable sources.  
(example:  Candle holders repurposed from wine bottles.  Cool, huh?!)

Trace = privado seating if you want it.  Public seating if you don't.

Trace = a far improvement from XYZ's high prices, flashy lights, and low substance

Trace = my latest choice when I'm in the mood for great food (on a date or with friends) in a chic and sexy environment.
author: Angella S.

description: The food here is pretty blah. I came here for a work lunch and I had the steak and frits. Pretty unmemorable meal. The place is probably good for large work lunches, but I think I would pick Chevy's across the street over this place.
author: Alice W.

description:
I have to say I'm very surprised at Trace's low average at the time of this review. I suspect that it's due in large part to the fact that the highly anticipated restaurant in the W opened during one of the craziest times of the year for this neighborhood - a huge Oracle convention thing that took over the streets for a week. I'm confident that based on their excellent waitstaff service alone that soon the average will creep up. 

As for my own personal experience, I very much enjoyed myself at a lunch with my coworkers a couple of weeks ago. I made a reservation earlier but the place was pretty empty when we walked in at 12:30 on a Monday... I was surprised, especially after so many people griping about how long they'd had to wait in the past! The hostess was lovely but no one compared to our waitress (kicking myself for not remember her name), who was charming, funny, helpful and efficient all the way. She alone gets five stars!

As for the food, there were hits and misses I'd say. We used our handy dandy Yelp check-ins to get two free shared dishes, which were the charcuterie board and a pork belly flatbread pizza, both of which were incredible! I think these were definitely the high points of the meal. For my entree, I got the pork belly BLT which was just fine (the pork belly was heavenly), but I wasn't too impressed with the potato chip side or the bread that was used. My dining companions weren't huge fans of the rabbit club or ahi tuna either... neither were terrible but just maybe not too special.

However, I highly recommend saving room for dessert. Our lovely waitress was nice enough to send over two complimentary desserts for our group and I practically had to ask my coworkers to restrain me to my chair so that I wouldn't lunge for all of this light almond panna cotta they sent out. 

One major tip: turn down the AC! We were all shivering like crazy eating our meals, even though it was sunny and fairly mild outside. I had to order a cup of hot tea just to be able to get through the meal! It didn't help that the ambiance of the place is pretty sterile and cold too, with lots of sharp lines and white furniture. For a place that serves some pretty soulful farm-to-table cuisine, the atmosphere could be a bit warmer to match!
author: Christina P.

description:
Had lunch here with a colleague and we shared our apps and entrees.

4 stars for the attentiveness of the staff, particularly our server and while it was a busy lunch hour for the restaurant. the crew managed to keep the place serene and in order and we did not feel rushed at all.

3 stars for the food which was mostly well executed but the options were neither new nor exciting to me. The steak was cooked perfectly as we had ordered. The crispy gnocchi was the best part of our meal, for sure. They captured the crisp without the grease. 

The brussells sprouts app, on the other hand, had a good flavor but they served the dish with all the oil the sprouts were fried, so it was not so appetizing if you're not into the sensation of oil squishing in your mouth at every bite.

I'd visit again for dinner or cocktails upstairs.
author: Carlo I.

description:
Being that Trace is just a hop, skip, and jump from my workplace... it was only a matter of time until I had an opportunity to pop in and nibble on the nosh at the latest iteration of the former XYZ space within the W Hotel. And upon dipping my fork into many 'a bites from Executive Chef Paul Piscopo's farm-to-table eats, I gotta say... I'm pretty fond of what they're doing. 

This is no knock on the former tenant, but for me, the W used to stand for cutting edge style, fashion, and culture. Whether you were at one of their properties in San Diego, Chicago, or San Francisco, you knew that if you were eating, sleeping, or flirting at one of their outposts, it was one of the hottest hangs in town. But for some reason (complacency, perhaps?), the W seemed to fall behind the rest of the pack when it came to forward thinking concepts... but that's all changed with the turnover project of Trace.

To run with the theme of the W's former cutting edge spirit, they're back to their old ways with one of the first locally-sourced, farm-to-table operations in any hotel I can recall. When was the last time you visited a hotel and encountered meats from grass-fed animals that were procured from within 90 miles of the front door? Greens hailing from a farm just a quick 45 minute drive away? Dishes featuring Bellwether Farms Carmody cheese, so close, you can almost hit it with a rock? Often times when you're eating at a hotel, you're stuck ingesting horrible factory-farmed products and Cisco processed franken-food. Bravo to the brass at W for jumping aboard the trendy, yet much-needed and appreciated slow food movement that many other visionaries around San Francisco have been practicing as of late. 

Doting aside... how does all this backyard fare play out? Well, let me recall some of the flavorful items that found their way ol' Ruggeford H. Joesten's eagerly-awaiting palate.

+ The spiced eggplant with grilled scallion, coriander and crispy rice: a fantastic little starter with all the smokiness you'd expect from a pureed nightshade like this. 

+ Brentwood corn soup with spiced popcorn, cotija cheese, and cilantro cream: it's the tail end of corn season, but this little bugger still packed quite the punch. Served cold, it's a must try if you're fortunate enough to catch it before it goes away until 2012.

+ The heirloom tomato "PBLT" with grilled pork belly, romaine, aioli, whole wheat, and of course, bacon: Well, it had both pork belly AND bacon. It shouldn't take too much convincing to let you know it was divine, porky gluttony. 

+ The grilled flatbread with  figs, caramelized onions, pork belly, arugula: again, our pal pork belly makes another appearance, and this dish is perfect for sharing as a starter. Not too heavy despite the fatty hunks of swine scattered throughout, and the figs help to offset the salty nature of the rest of the ingredients.

Yes... there's even more food!

+ Prosciutto and Fig grilled cheese sandwich featuring Valley Ford cheddar cheese, whole grain mustard, and crispy sourdough: with the gourmet grilled cheese crazy seeing no end in sight, the stand right in there with some of the bigger names you'd come to expect from the high-end comfort food game. 

+ And finally, for dessert... quite possibly one of my favorite sweet indulgences I've had in some kind. I can't recall the name of this one, but it featured a peanut butter waffle (yes, a peanut butter waffle!) with housemade Concord grape jelly, chocolate chips, and a dollop of crème fraiche on top. Holy cow -- it was like eating the greatest peanut butter and jelly sandwich of my life! Seriously, this might be one of the greatest dessert items in all of San Francisco.

So, as you can see... I'm fairly pleased with my first romp with Trace. I see some of these neg reviews from folks who waited a couple extra minutes during one of the busiest times of year in SOMA (Oracle World), and it's a shame, as it's a tad unfair to judge a place at the height of the pandemonium that Larry Ellison brings to downtown. Hopefully they'll have an opportunity to swing by on a less intense evening.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Great restaurant, great waiter, very accommodating for us and our baby.  I would definitely come back again. The steak and salmon were amazing!
author: Erik T.

description: Our dining party started with the Chantrelle Mushroom Flatbread (mornay, bacon, brussels sprouts, agrumato), which was beyond delightful. I could honestly sit and eat three of those, call it a night, be quite happy. A few gourmet cocktails from the bar and we were in seventh heaven. I had the pork, my one friend had the chicken, and my third friend had the steak entrees, all were 4/5 overall. Nothing quite measured up to the appetizer and drinks, but it was a beautiful setting, a nice night, and we were quite happy with the quality, the service, and the reasonable price for high-end cuisine.
author: Sean B.

description:
Love the concept. Locally sourced and sustainable.  The ingredients in your meal can be TRACEd back to its origin. However, I think the concept could be followed through more.

We had a pasta dish with short rib. I expected the pasta to be made in-house but it wasn't. I asked our server and he told us it's not fresh pasta. It's imported from Italy. What happened to locally sourced?

Also, I had a blood orange cocktail called the bloody sunrise. It was garnished with a wedge of regular orange not blood orange. Where is the blood orange? Apparently, they don't use fresh fruits in their cocktails. It was a blood orange liqueur. At a place where they pride on their locally sourced ingredients, I expected market fresh fruit cocktails especially at $13 a pop. An option of non-alcoholic fresh fruit house made sodas/drinks would be nice as well.

I was with 3 other people so I was able to sample of variety of dishes. Food was great but not mind blowing. The food here reminds me of the food from Prospect. 

The stand out dishes of the night were the braise pork gnocchi app, squid app and the chicken entree.

One of the desserts we had was the panna cotta and it was tiny. I could have eaten the whole thing in one big bite. Not kidding. Especially compared to the two other desserts we had (red velvet cake and chocolate bar, they were good not great). The size of the other desserts were normal. Not sure what they were thinking when they made the panna cotta.

The food prices were on point (~$23 per entree) but cocktails were way overpriced. At $13 a glass it was more than what most of their appetizers cost (~$10 each). However, I do like the fact that soda refills are complimentary.

Service was fine. We liked our quirky server but he disappeared for long periods of time in between courses.

The space is modern and loud. One of my friends said the space reminded him of a Virgin America plane. White wall, table and chairs, purple and pink lighting, trance music... he was right on.  The second floor is a bar/lounge area with a DJ blasting music. The second floor is open so you can kind of see what's going on when you look up. Anyway, not a place to have dinner and a conversation.
author: Andy W.

description: Came here for dinner late last night before a masquerade party.  We shared the rib eye, Brussels sprouts and cheesy corn.  Everything was selfish especially the Brussels sprouts.  Service was great as well.
author: Kim K.

description:
This place is in the W Hotel and is a trendy and cute spot, great to start off a girls night out before you hit the town, as my girls and I did. One of my girlfriends and I were planning a dinner to for us girls to reunite, drink, eat and be merry during the Dine About Town month. As I was scanning down the list of restaurants participating in DAT, I came across Trace and the menu they had set up was very appealing. I suggested it to my girlfriends and one received the ok's jumped on making reservations, which turned out to be a great choice.  There was 4 of us and decided to share 2 DAT courses, to prevent food comas prior to heading to the club.

We all shared the following: 
Roasted Beat Salad: Persimmonn, burrata, pistachio roof top lettuces and honey - This was nice and light   
Butternut Squash Risotto: Pine nuts, sage, crème fraiche - This was really tasty and I think my fav dish of the night
Seared East Coast Scallops: Peasant's angel hair pasta, tamari, fort bragg uni - This was very good and the scallops were cooked perfectly
Roasted Chicken Breast: Lollipop kale, kabocha squash, crispy chicken confitpistachio aigre-doux - Only had a tiny bite, but from what I did try it had good flavor and not dry
Chocolate Crème Bar: Hazelnut ice cream, cherries - This was delish and not too sweet

I will def come back and try their brunch.
author: Candice B.

description: The desserts are TRACE are really interesting and tasty things, and I recommend trying one or two after a meal. The dinner isn't cheap, but I've had some seasonal fish dishes that really hit the spot. I had a $25 gift card which I took as an excuse to go lunch-crazy on a ridiculous, fancy burger (I added a crab cake and avocados which came out to about the value of the card - it came with a small house slaw) and it was tasty, but not juicy or bloody enough. For free, yes, certainly not worth $25 dollars and if I ordered it again I would ask for it rare and skip the crab cake which added very little in the way of flavor. Nice ambiance, a great liquor/wine list (the beer selection is not too impressive), overall I do enjoy TRACE.
author: Jillian N.

description:
Came here for DAT lunch 6/6/14 with a friend, we had a hot mess of a day with scheduling and communication ( she lost her phone, I was driving all day, no bueno) BUT. we managed to get to TRACE for our DAT lunch.

My salad was wonderful, had huge portions of grilled beets that were cooked perfectly. I have NEVER liked beets and I really enjoyed the way TRACE prepared them. Sweet but not overly sweet, with a nice bite. There was burrata as well ( gah to die for )and the greens were fresh and crunchy! 

My pork shoulder was flavorful and the fried gnocchi made me feel spoiled eating it :) The portions were huge!!

But my highlight of this meal was my server - we were the only table left ( we came right before closing at lunch time ) AND I was late. He kept the food warm for me, was gracious and so kind. Thank you for making my lunch such a nice one!!

Seating in here is beautiful and can be very intimate, so this place would be wonderful for a date or dinner with a loved one :)
author: Selina W.

description:
We stumbled upon Trace on accident, but quickly noticed that their brunch menu looked better than the one we were headed toward.
The service was great! Especially when I mentioned that I was celiac, the server said 'just tell me what you want, and we'll do a modification to make it gluten free if we can'. First thing I asked for....they did! I had the Benedict. (they had gfree bread in the back).
It is clean, bright, and beautiful inside the venue as well. We loved everything about it!
author: Amanda T.

description:
I often come here for dinner after (corporate) drinks in SOMA. The place is a hidden gem: modern, spacious, and delicious.

Never crowded, most of TRACE's patrons belong to the W hotel, which means that there's always room for the city savvy corporate guy who needs to find an elegant table for his elegant ladies at the last minute.

Order the champagne, oysters, and pasta.
author: Kanishk P.

description:
I was pleasently surprised that I enjoyed dining here. Enjoyed a delicious dinner with excellent service the other evening with friends while watching the rain fall. 
Started with a delicious flatbread with cheese, sausage and some other toppings I don't recall, followed by a main course of pasta with broccolini. At the beginning of the meal, was offered a choice of delicious homemade breads to sample, of which I chose the olive bread. I'd definitely go back! Extensive wine list looked great, but I opted instead for a glass of iced tea with a shot of Triple Sec.
author: David G.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded down. 

We came here for Dine About Town this past Wednesday.  The food was alright, but it wasn't so amazingly delicious that I would go around recommending that everyone come  here for DAT.  

Food: 
I ordered the butternut squash risotto, the hangar steak, and the chocolate carre.  The butternut squash risotto was quite good - hearty, nutty, and slightly reminiscent of mac 'n cheese.  It was just a tad bit saltier than I would've liked, but then again, I tend to like things to be blander so that could just be a personal preference thing.  The hangar steak was well-cooked, but also a bit salty.  I enjoyed it but felt like it was nothing to write home about.  The bed of kale that it sat on was good but again, not mind-blowing.  The steak also came with a side of fries.  The chocolate carre was pretty awesome, but I was pretty full by the end of the meal so didn't finish the entire thing.  I'm not sure if it was a mousse or something else, but whatever it was, it was yummy!  It also came with some ice cream (salted caramel, mayhaps?) and some crumbles of something, which I really enjoyed!

My boyfriend had the seared scallops and pasta entree; I tried a bite of the scallops and it tasted well-cooked.  The one strand of pasta I tried seemed really greasy.  Also tried his bread pudding, which I thought was quite good.

Service: 
Service was quite good, as expected from a trendy place like this.  Instead of giving you a basket of bread, they come by with a basket, and ask you what you want, and then put a slice of bread on your bread plate.  When my boyfriend went to use the restroom, a server walked up, picked up the napkin from the seat, and re-folded and put it back on the table.  Generally, attentive, good service.

Atmosphere:
So, when it comes to nicer restaurants, I prefer warmer and more intimate settings, maybe with some dim, yellow-ish, soft lighting.  This was the exact opposite, and I did not like that.  Most of the furniture is white, the place has a trendy feel, and the entire room felt kind of cold and sterile.  Also, it was quite empty, so that certainly didn't help.  I think the cold atmosphere is a big reason why I can't see myself coming back here.  If I'm going to spend a bit more money on food, I'd rather have a nicer, warmer place where it feels cozy and intimate.  

Overall, good - but not great - food, attentive service, and cold/sterile atmosphere.  I enjoyed the meal, but I'm not raving about the place.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Had a recovery brunch here a couple of weekends ago whilst staying at the W. The space is nice and well lit, right next to the bar space with a funky bearded Mission hipster dj playing old school soul,  disco and hip hop on his MacBook. 
Food was pretty decent and there seemed to be a good portion of non hotel guest diners specially there for Sunday brunch. 

Issue? They need to revise their hiring policy in the restaurant and not hire affected wannabes in their establishment. We had a male waiter and a male server and both acted like the sun shone out of their behinds. The middle aged preened waiter was the worst. Super patronizing and a complete douche.  I'd expect this in LA where I'm from, but SF? What a downer. 

Trace management, fix his attitude.
author: Jon Z.

description:
Make way for....well, nobody.  The place was empty when we walked in at 12:05pm for a client lunch.

The servers were attentive, friendly and accommodating for our hard stop at 1pm.

The menu is pricey - but hey it's the W, I get it.  I ordered the Albacore Tuna Quinoa salad w/fennel and looked at the price $22, OUCH - for a SALAD.  The others I was with all ordered the Chicken Sandwich w/jalapeno aioli and kettle chips for $16, much more reasonable (although still pricey for a sandwich).

The plates came out pretty quickly and I was immediately disappointed.  Maybe it's the survival of the fittest instincts or my own savagery - but when a $22 salad comes out with what looks like the proper proportions for a high cholesterol ridden overweight 75 year old desperately trying to lose weight...I nearly flipped over the table.  I'm not a small rodent who might nibble.  I like to EAT. Anyways - for a $22 salad, I was offended by the small size of it.

As I was eating it I noticed that the wasabi dressing was smeared on the bottom of my plate and it took me eating almost my entire salad to notice.  Since that was the only thing that had flavor on my plate, I was rather annoyed.  Who puts dressing on the bottom of a salad plate?

Also - you know when you occasionally go to an iffy place, a diner, or a take a risk restaurant when you are traveling sometimes?  And then you order something, take a bite and your teeth grind on something that shouldn't be there? (WORST feeling in the world if you ask me) Well that happened when I took a bite of the fish in my salad. I got over it pretty quick though - because it was just a fish bone.  But still. For $22, I expected that fish to be nothing short of delicious and prepared as such.

Bottom line: Don't go unless you have to.
author: Lauren B.

description: Had the most wonderful experience at Trace today. After visiting MOMA, headed down the street to a restaurant that I had only read about on YELP. I can only reiterate all the positive comments echoed by so many others. Shared three starters with a friend. When I mentioned it was my birthday, I received the most delicious carrot cake imaginable!. The staff is outstanding, gracious, knowledgeable and ever so professional. Would highly recommend Trace for lunch~save room for the carrot cake. I plan to return for the brunch!
author: me m.

description:
Beautiful restaurant in a beautiful hotel! Dined here with the amazing BF for his early Bday dinner :D 

We ordered:

Yellowtail crudo and Pacific oysters - starters
Roasted chicken (BF's entree)
Duck breast (my order)
Complimentary champagne from the awesome waiter!!!

Food was DELICIOUS. Ambience/decor A+++
Great place to bring your date :D

After dinner, my BF and I walked over to the bar area, shared a few drinks, and enjoyed some music. I had a blast w/ my man!!! :D Will definitely dine here again when we stay at the W!
author: Clara Y.

description:
This place, in the W, has an identity crisis. Its a good, fine dining, restaurant trying too hard to be hip. Why? stop. please stop. The strip steak was reeaaaally good, but why serve it un-cut? I thought i was at Dennys. Your high brow counter-parts, whom are probably  aware that electronic music is finally getting its 15 minutes of fame, would have cut the fat off the sides for me. Why didn't you do it? What is wrong?

 =(

See, I am a very trusting person. If you put it on my plate, i will eat it. If presentation is something you value (which you clearly do with your hilarious signs above the urinals), then make it so that everything visible is also edible. When you make me chew on a band of fat for 5 mins, i have to spit it out. where do i spit it? its unsightly. I was with my parents, so i didnt care but what if it was last week when i was on a date with Parker Posey?  

What? Dont know who that is? It's because you are not hip, and turn on the god damn lights cause I cant see shit. While you're at it, turn off the music. If I could hear myself think, I would have picked WINE for the WINE pairings. Instead, in my techno-trance daze, i ordered the theatrical martinis at the same time the gay parade on the 2nd floor did. 

The strawberry lemonade with basil and mint leaves were amazing.
author: Gianni J.

description:
I was there for a quick celebration lunch for a coworker who was promoted. The restaurant was very clean and organized-looking. It had a nice, high-class vibe to it. I was trying to be healthy that day, so I had the gem lettuce & castelfranco radiocchio salad ($9, fuji apple, dates, candied pecan, cheddar dressing). It was absolutely delicious! It was also drenched in dressing, so if you're not a dressing type of person, I suggest you get the dressing on the side. It was just the right combination of ingredients for your taste bud.

For the entree, I had the roasted heirloom cauliflower ($15, gomen, baby carrot, masala spiced potato & crispy ginger). I was intrigued how half of the cauliflowers were purple. It was a really nice presentation. I like the potatoes a lot, as well as the gomen and baby carrot. The cauliflower, which was supposed to be the highlight, was a bit disappointing. It tasted bland compared to the surrounding side vegetables.

Overall, this is a nice place, but a bit pricey. I heard the bar is great, so I'll have to try that some time. Great service, too, as expected for a restaurant inside a fancy hotel, the W.
author: Vera W.

description: This review is really for both Trace and the Lounge of the W Hotel.  I have actually only been here for brunch and in the lounge for happy hour.  Typically I don't hang out in hotels, but this one is really cool.  The lounge is good for happy hour, on the weekends-possibly every day there is a dj playing music.  Brunch on Sundays they have a dj too.  This is typically when I have come.  The menu is really good.  I have only had the bagel and lox, and mimosa's of course but have gone with friends and they always enjoy their meals as well.  Overall, great atmosphere, even better music and good food!
author: nikki g.

description:
food: 3
service: 4
ambience: 4
location: 5

I've only tried the brunch there. Loved the modern ambience. The server was pretty friendly. 

The food, however, is a bit disappointing. The presentation of the french toast was absolutely fantastic but the taste was at most average. The coffee was not remarkable and the Mimosa was a little too sour. 

That being said, it was still a pretty positive experience. My friend was happy with her breakfast platter, we had a good time catching up in a super relaxing atmosphere. 

Tip:
If you check in on Yelp from your phone, you can get a shared appetizer with purchase of 2 entries (at least this is the case when i visited a week ago). However they only make the appetizers at dinner time so technically it only works for dinner entries, but our server was kind enough to waive the coffee and cocktail from our bill :)
author: Rachel Z.

description: Really good!!! From the appetizer to the drinks to the main course!! Outstanding!! And our server Shawn was awesome!!
author: Carrie T.

description: Nice service, good food presentation, taste is average. Pricy but what you expect, you are paying for the scene. Cinnabon roll was kind of old, the sweet on top of it tasted good. This review was for breakfast/brunch time
author: Lacomida C.

description:
Came here for brunch with a large group of visiting family members. I did not care for the savory french toast I ordered- interesting concept but something about the flavor combination was unappealing.

The rest of the group seemed to enjoy their meals, though everything was quite pricey for not-that-impressive.

My main beef with this place is that they demanded a credit card for the reservation and threatened me with a $25 per person cancellation fee for a no-show. I can understand if they were turning away other business to accommodate my group of 12 but we were quite literally the only souls in the place. Rude. This place is on my never again list.
author: OnlyatBrandei S.

description: I still love the XYZ bar. The bartenders and servers are all fantastic. And, the food is very good as well. We've had the burger several times since my last review. I mentioned my issue to one of the bartenders, and he made sure the burger turned out right. Also, the management followed up with me after my last review to assure me that the next time I came it, the burger would be up to my expectations. And, I have to say, the burgers have been great since then. The only missing star is because I miss the brioche bun, the aioli we used to get, and the fingerling potatoes. But, I understand that times change, as do recipes and ingredients. And, I know most customers probably prefer the french fries to the fingerling potatoes.
author: Leslie L.

description: Tried this place for breakfast during my stay for a corporate event. Good food and very friendly service. Eggs chilaquiles are tasty but on the heavy side. Good coffee. So why only 3 stars? Well, it's overpriced for the quality (eggs at $20). You can get much better quality food elsewhere for cheaper, either in the financial district or in the mission.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I can't say that I was overwhelmed by Trace - not that I need to find myself in an 'overwhelmed' state every time I dine.  BUT, I do expect that a restaurant in the W should provide more than they did.

We went for brunch with friends on a Saturday.  The place wasn't particularly busy when we went, but for some reason the service was pretty slow.  The menu was good - they seemed to offer something for everyone on there. 

At our table we ordered the market omelette, trace breakfast, poached eggs and huckleberry pancakes.  While the food tasted good and was prepared well, we all noticed that the food was not hot, only lukewarm...as if it has been sitting for some time.  Which it probably had because for whatever reason, things were just so slow that morning.  Drinks came out slow, and only after we asked a few times first. We noticed other diners had been waiting a while for their food too...

Time to step up the game Trace - your food is good, but your service needs to match.
author: Christy L.

description:
Our server KIM made the experience INCREDIBLE! It was our honeymoon and we were very pleased with everything Kim did to make it even more special. 

We ordered steak (perfection) and chicken (great). TRACE provided complimentary items because it was our honeymoon and this made my wife happy which in turn made me happy. VERY DELIGHTED.

THANKS AGAIN KIM! We hope you see this!
author: Esco J.

description:
quality and flavor disappeared without a trace.....

Service - 3 stars - friendly but no where on par with a top quality restaurant

Food:
1. salad starter 1 star....boooooooorrrrrriiinnnngggg....
2. pork main 2 stars.....pork was a dry, and quite flavorless.  The only good thing was a lentils which was yummy
3. bread pudding 1 star - booooorrrrrriiiinnnngggg

Then in the middle of this expensive dinner ($100 pp), they start taking chairs and tables away all around us for some party....geezzz!  How CLASSLESS!  Look folks, if you schedule a private party then DO NOT allow RSVPs for dinner the same night.  I will NOT be rushed when spending $100 pp for dinner!

So lame!

And the dreadful wallpaper....good grief, I know they were trying for the artistic distressed look but unfortunately, the only thing it looked like was a poorly conceived dirty wall.......

I would not return and would not recommend it.
author: Lev E.

description:
We came here for brunch and found it pretty lackluster. Overall their dishes aren't too greasy or heavy so they have that nice healthy aspect to them. No fresh squeezed juices although the waitress claimed they were freshly pasteurized and still tasted good...whatever that means. 

Highlights were the steak and eggs and poached eggs. The steak was flavorful and cut into easy to eat pieces. As for poached eggs, they were atop prosciutto and the pair worked well. All the dishes had yummy yukon gold potatoes that were crispy and savory.

Misses were the omelette. The eggs were overcooked and the fillings were pretty scant and meager. Tasted like styrofoam with hints of egg. The blood mary pizza was basically a raw pizza but the bread was stiff and the crushed tomatoes just tasted like something from the can. 

Our waitress was a major bitch, though. She had little patience to explain the menu to us and how the travelzoo deal worked. And then she'd talked really loudly with fake energy but you could tell lacked any genuine sincerity. My parents may have a slight language barrier but they're definitely not stupid and definitely didn't deserve that treatment!
author: Annie W.

description:
Great birthday breakfast.
Had prosciutto and poached eggs.
Thank God for discount.
author: Josh G.

description:
Had an awesome experience here for brunch, which is my favorite meal. 

Had low expectations given it is a hotel restaurant but was pleasantly surprised. 

The pancakes with poached pear and vanilla cream were excellent. Perhaps the best I've had in the city. The chicken sandwich was also awesome. Light. Tasty. Healthy. 

Will def go back... and they take reservations which is rare for good sf brunch spots.
author: Raza M.

description: Dinner for 7; Roger our waiter was exceptional! The liver mousse starter was delish. My BF had the scallops they were cooked to perfection! I had the Rib eye which by far was the best I've ever had - it's my favorite cut of meat and it was cooked so perfectly paired with the mash potatoes yum, yum!! The lemongrass cocktail was a plus. Trying breakfast there this morning lol..
author: Erika G.

description:
We were walking towards Union Square to do some shopping from the Embarcadero and needed a place to get brunch so we decided to give Trace a try at the W hotel. 

They have a great happy hour breakfast menu from 11am-1pm. Mimosas ($5) Bloody Mary ($7) and a few other selections including savory and sweet bites. We ordered from the regular brunch menu the market omelette which came with potatoes+bacon+toast and the chilaquiles (my fav);  we were fighting for the last bite not to mention huge portions. Additionally, the service was pleasant and speedy. We are looking forward to returning since it's just a short walk from home.
author: Maria C.

description: I love almost every W Hotel I visit or stay at. We went in for brunch and  everything from the service to the food was great. Lots of creative dishes being served here.
author: Mark G.

description:
Atmosphere.......very modern , but welcoming.
Staff.... a bit slow on paying attention and follow-through to our requests.
Food........a medium grade.
A bit overpriced, in spite of being   at the W in San Francisco.

Would I go back, aaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhhhhhhh      NO.
author: Craig C.

description:
Dropped in after a movie, as we wanted to get a couple drinks and maybe an appetizer of some sort.

One drink each, and a shared brussel sprout flatbread... $56

Now I suppose if someone else is picking up the tab, and you really like loud suit-wearing drinkers, and you're on crutches and staying in the hotel... then this place might be 5 stars.

But even when adjusting for the "gonna get bad service because it's a hotel bar" and "gonna be overpriced because it's a hotel bar", I still can't justify giving it 3 stars. It's a 2 and a half, rounded down.
author: TJ P.

description:
Just went for the first time tonight with some friends, I'm definitely a fan! Since it's a Monday it was really low key in the restaurant, not too crowded which is how I like it. We were quickly seated by the host. Plus, I'm already a huge fan of the W Hotel chain, (such a chic, flirty, and contemporary property) so the ambiance itself truly complimented the experience. 

First off, our server Roger was excellent. He gave great recommendations on his personal favorite entrees and never let our wine/water glasses get empty. Fantastic service overall, the entire waitstaff were extremely attentive and knowledgeable of the menu. (which is what is expected at a restaurant of this caliber). 

Food wise, I got the seared east coast scallops which were perfectly seared and seasoned (serving size is four scallops). The angel hair pasta was a bit salty and greasy though, didn't really wow me.  It was a great dish but I probably wouldn't get it again, I will definitely experiment with the other menu items in the future. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Evin C.

description:
Had the fortune of coming here and trying the food at Trace as part of a Yelp Elite event, as I wouldn't have normally chosen to eat at hotel restaurants on a regular basis. The interior was classy yet fun, dark yet lit with creative colorful lighting in just the right areas. All the staff were super friendly and nice. 
There was a large sampling menu, free flowing champagne, wine, and beer, as well as a dessert station complete with panna cotta topped with satsuma mandarins and liquid nitrogen ice cream in the style of Smitten. The ice cream was rich and decadent; it came in either honey or chocolate flavors, topped with whatever toppings of your choice. 
The food itself was very delicious, I can't remember every detail of everything, but I was very impressed all around. Yellowtail sashimi (topped with so many complementary toppings, I can't name them all) was top notch. Pumpkin raviolis were rich and melty. We got to sample the braised lamb shoulder with potato gnocchi. Textures on both were soft, tender, and delicate. Next was the pork belly on some special kind of lentil. I really enjoyed the crispy skin there. There was also lumpia, pork buns, and braised duck, but I think those aren't traditionally on the Trace menu. And right when we were about to leave, they brought out some surprise steak with mushroom and veggies! hahah talk about switching back and forth between savory and sweet! :P
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I really enjoyed my trip to Trace with a colleague. I was attempting to be healthy so had a blue cheese salad, my colleague had another type of salad. We also shared the little chicken meatballs which were really tasty. Needless to say I left no TRACE on my plate (mwa ha ha). 

I liked the decor. It was weird. Kind of like I was in some kind of Tom Cruise generic space film (take your pick on which one), with a little cool dusted on the top for good luck. It's difficult to explain sans photos. I'd go back though.
author: Rosie A.

description: Absolutely phenomenal breakfast. Pricey, but really high-quality. I've been back several times!
author: Rajesh S.

description: This is just my second time here since I'm from SoCal but this place gives "world class service"... From the initial greeting to Roger who served us everything and was on point .. Btw we found out that they grow their own honey onsite( rooftop- but sounds like a mission impossible to get up there ) Roger is the "BeeMan",,, all the way to Jeremy our bartender who made those dirty Martinis like no other...if you haven't been to this "gem" them you are missing out .. Oh and try their oxtail soup and beets salad... They're amazing!!! Thanks again Trace!! See you back soon!!!
author: T G.

description:
I came here for the Yelp Elite event and was very impressed. The decor was a bit cheesy, in that clubby neon lights sort of way, but it worked. The standout dish of the night was the braised lamb shoulder and gnocchi -- the meat melted away on the tongue, and the gnocchi was equally tender and drenched in a flavorful bolognese sauce. 

Had champagne the whole night so can't really speak for the cocktails. I will say that I tried this pink-colored cocktail which tasted just like cherry cough syrup, ugh. But their jello shots, believe it or not, were another story.

When I see jello shots, I think: sticky floors, icky frat boys and cheap liquor. But Trace elevates the jello shot to a whole new level. When the waiter began calling out, "JELLO SHOTS!", I instinctively began shaking my head no, until I noticed he appeared to be holding slices of lemon (my weakness, as I love sour). It looked and tasted like a more sophisticated piece of candy, with sugar and salt and real lemon flavors. But it was a jello shot, make no mistake, and I will never forget it! Worth stopping by Trace just for this experience.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
------brunch only-------
Had a travelzoo offer which made this place worth coming to.

Decor is BEAUTIFUL. It's modern, it's hip, it's great if you have uppity LA friends that you want to impress. Half kidding but really though, it's a nice setting for brunch. 

Food is just okay. It's not bad but for how much it is (WITHOUT the travelzoo), the taste isn't really worth the price. That being said, it's still good. Just not amazing.

Service is pretty hit or miss. The first time I came here, our waitress took 25 min just to take our order (after we had to flag her down to get our drink order) and then it took another 45 minutes to GET our food (we had to ask for it, so we have a feeling she forgot to put the order in since it wasn't even crowded). However, the SECOND time I came here, the waiter was attentive, quick and really friendly. So, I guess it just depends on who you get.
author: Diana Y.

description: This review is really for the staff. I went to a Yelp Elite event, and not only were the apps great but the staff was so generous to ensure that there was enough food for everyone -- they definitely worked their butts off and it's much appreciated!
author: Siv L.

description:
ok portions for dinner, nice ambiance. walking by so I came in to give a try.  Food was just ok, sea bass with sprouts and carrots?  interesting combo.  I think fish would taste better without the sprouts and carrots on top.

I'd like to come back and try their weekend happy hour breakfast!
author: CherryIcee S.

description: Showed up 8 minutes late for a reservation for lunch on Thanksgiving and was told they closed the kitchen and could only serve us the bar menu and not in the main dining room where several other diners looked to be enjoying their meal. And despite the 1 pm reservation we made, and lack of any notice, they informed us when we arrived that they took their last seatings at 12:45 pm because they were preparing for a private party later that afternoon. I've eaten at Trace several times since it opened and this was the first bad experience, but this was exceptionally unprofessional and unexpected from a restaurant in a W Hotel.
author: Gene T.

description: I just got take out here.  The salmon with risotto.  The salmon was cooked perfectly and the risotto was moist and tasty.  The bill was $35 and the salmon was about 5oz.  For SF, I guess that's a decent price, but overall I wouldn't come back and try to find another place to serves more to what you pay for.
author: David L.

description: Came here with a travelzoo coupon. The food was good, but a little small in quantity. I thought it was a pretty good deal with the coupon but I wouldn't pay full price for the meal. The drinks here were super strong! the bloody mary was quite good.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Celebrated a girlfriend's bachelorette party a few weekends ago. We stayed the night at W Hotel and decided to try out TRACE for dinner since it was close.

The hostess was sweet, greeting us and seating us right away. I noticed the place wasn't busy at all but thought nothing of it until later on.

We were sat and waited a while for our server to come, even longer after we ordered our food, and were not checked on again until we asked to be. There were only two other tables seated so it was very inexcusable.

The food? Disappointing. I ordered the Farro and White Bean soup, it was "meh", along with an asparagus flatbread which was okay.

One friend ordered a medium-well burger which came out rare and I also shared the Chicken Meatballs with the bride-to-be and they were dry. It would have been more edible if they served more sauce.

Finally, another friend ordered the Fregola Sarda "Risotto." Let me just say, it was nothing like a "risotto" and when we spoke with the manager, she explained they named it that to let people know it's the closest thing to a risotto. I'm sorry, I've never seen or tasted a risotto so dry. 

The manager was nice enough to comp the meal without us asking after we told her our thoughts about the food and service. If it were packed we would understand not being checked on but it wasn't and we felt forgotten.

Needless to say, I won't be eating there again.
author: Lolly F.

description: I have come here for both brunch and dinner, and was impressed both times.  Brunch includes pretty standard brunch dishes, but they are executed well and served with solid drinks.  For dinner, make sure to get the duck, as that was the highlight of everyone's dinner (and the item of envy for those who were unfortunate enough to order something else).
author: Josh Q.

description:
Went there this morning to use a coupon (2 entrees + 2 drinks for $25). The meal was good, given the coupon, but probably would not go back on my own. We ordered the blueberry ricotta pancakes and steak and eggs. Both were pretty tasty. The pancakes were fluffy, just how I like them. We also had a bloody mary and a fresh orange carrot juice. The meal came with coconut water.
